title: Local Alcoholic's Single Beer Deemed Medically Necessary
excerpt: Meds evolving: Doctors prescribe one beer for 'robust' drinkers.
content:
The esteemed medical community has once again pushed the boundaries of conventional wisdom, with the unprecedented declaration that a solitary unit of [lager](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lager) has been deemed clinically indispensable for a local resident grappling with, shall we say, a *robust* appreciation for fermented grains. This groundbreaking pronouncement, following extensive consultation (presumably involving a stethoscope and a nuanced understanding of "just one more"), redefines preventative care, suggesting that abstention, for some, is a far more perilous path than controlled indulgence. The patient, identified only as "Mr. Tipple," reportedly experienced an immediate, albeit temporary, stabilization of vital signs upon administration of the therapeutic beverage.

Experts from the [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/) were unavailable for comment, likely still processing the implications for global public health guidelines on alcohol consumption. Meanwhile, local insurers are reportedly scrambling to update their policies, with "one-beer-a-day" now potentially covered under "essential prophylactic interventions." One can only imagine the surge in "medically necessary" prescription requests. The [American Medical Association](https://www.ama-assn.org/) has yet to issue a definitive stance on this innovative approach to addiction management, though sources suggest a lively debate is brewing.
author: Walking 503 Error

title: Local Man Still Manages to Fucking Lose Digital ID
excerpt: Gov ID: Badger-speed rollout. Starmer calls it 'cornerstone'.
content:
The government’s latest triumph of innovation, the national [Digital ID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_identity) scheme, is reportedly progressing with the swiftness of a badger on a particularly urgent quest for truffles. Touted by [Keir Starmer](https://www.gov.uk/government/people/keir-starmer) as a cornerstone of the nation’s enlightened [immigration strategy](https://www.gov.uk/government/policies/immigration-system), this marvel of modern bureaucracy promises a singular, unassailable digital fingerprint for every living soul. No more pesky physical documents, no more inconvenient paper trails; just pure, unadulterated data, perfectly secure, perfectly accessible. What could possibly go wrong?

Apparently, quite a lot, if our unnamed local protagonist is any indication. Despite being entirely digital, requiring only a smartphone, an internet connection, and perhaps a functioning memory, this individual has reportedly managed to misplace their unique identifier. One can only assume it’s vanished into the ether alongside their last sensible thought, or perhaps been inadvertently deleted while attempting to clear their browser history of incriminating cat videos.

This startling development raises profound questions about the future of national security. If one can simply "lose" a supposedly unloseable digital marker, what hope do we have for actual border control? Perhaps the next innovation will involve embedding these IDs directly into the skull, a foolproof method until someone misplaces their head.
author: Gigolo Joe

title: New Crypto Conversion Rate Tied To Neighbor's Lawn Care Schedule
excerpt: Crypto's new anchor: your neighbor's gardening schedule. Robust.
content:
The notoriously fickle world of digital finance has finally found its anchor: the diligent application of turf management. In a move praised by exactly no one who still understands basic economics, the latest [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) conversion rates are now inextricably linked to your neighbor's gardening calendar. This paradigm shift, we are assured, offers a robust and entirely unpredictable alternative to historical financial indicators, especially for those grappling with persistent [market volatility](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/marketvolatility.asp).

Freelancers and the burgeoning ranks of [home-based businesses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home-based_business) are reportedly embracing this pioneering metric with the bewildered enthusiasm usually reserved for unsolicited email forwards. No longer must they fret over complex algorithms or global economic shifts; instead, the pristine lines of a freshly mown lawn or the tell-tale whine of a leaf blower now dictate their potential solvency. It provides a clarity utterly unparalleled by quaint concepts such as 'company profits' or 'supply and demand'.

One can only marvel at the sheer genius of replacing the arcane machinations of global financial markets with the far more accessible and equally arbitrary rhythm of suburban yard work. Truly, we've achieved a level of financial innovation that renders all previous notions of fiscal responsibility charmingly obsolete.

Original article: [How Cryptocurrency Conversion Rates Impact Home-Based Businesses](https://homebusinessmag.com/money/cryptocurrency/how-cryptocurrency-conversion-rates-impact-home-based-businesses/)

title: Tesla Stock Nears 2025 High, Full Self-Driving Still Vaporware
excerpt: Tesla shares achieve 2025 high, proving time is optional.
content:
The financial soothsayers have spoken, declaring that shares of [Tesla](https://www.tesla.com/) are hurtling towards a "2025 high," an impressive feat considering we are still firmly planted in the year prior. This forward-thinking valuation presumably accounts for the revolutionary breakthroughs promised, but not yet delivered, in its vaunted [Full Self-Driving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Autopilot#Full_Self-Driving) (FSD) suite. One must admire the market's unwavering faith in a future that remains perpetually just around the corner, much like that elusive level 5 autonomy.

While investors are busy high-fiving over future profits, the average Tesla owner is still largely in charge of, you know, *driving* their vehicle. FSD, the software that continually promises to whisk us away from the drudgery of steering, continues its magnificent evolution from "beta" to "advanced beta" to "almost definitely going to be ready next year, maybe." It’s truly a marvel of engineering, delivering an unparalleled experience in anticipatory software updates and the thrill of hoping your car doesn't mistake a shadow for a child.

Perhaps the greatest innovation isn't the electric vehicle itself, but the sheer market capitalization built upon the purest form of speculative optimism. [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk) must be truly proud of this future-proof strategy.

While the financial markets have long grappled with definitions, this initiative marks a watershed moment: a federal body stepping in to provide much-needed clarity on which speculative token, often inspired by abstract internet culture or a particularly compelling social media post, is genuinely worthy of your life savings.

Sources, who understandably wish to remain anonymous given the gravity of their mission, suggest the commission is developing a sophisticated framework. This might involve analyzing market sentiment fueled by enigmatic pronouncements from self-proclaimed digital savants, or perhaps assessing the sheer volume of "when moon" comments. The move is a clear nod to the clamor from [retail investors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retail_investor) who, tired of navigating the Wild West of emerging [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) offerings, simply yearn for a government-sanctioned shopping list. One can only assume the criteria will be as transparent and robust as the assets themselves. It’s certainly a unique approach to ensuring market integrity and avoiding widespread digital rug-pulls.

title: Convicted Drug Kingpin's Comeback: "it's Just Defi, Bro"

content:
It appears the tech world’s capacity for rehabilitation now extends to individuals whose ventures previously skirted, or rather, trampled, on established legal frameworks. [Ross Ulbricht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ross_Ulbricht), a name once synonymous with the illicit digital marketplace [Silk Road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silk_Road_(marketplace)), recently graced the stage as the closing orator at [Bitcoin 2025](https://bitcoinmagazine.com/conferences/bitcoin-2025). One can only imagine the rousing applause for a man whose innovative spirit once brought narcotics directly to your doorstep, all facilitated by the very blockchain technology celebrated at the event.

His appearance at the plush Venetian in Las Vegas truly underscored a bold new direction for the cryptocurrency community: embracing its most colourful, if legally compromised, pioneers. The subtext, naturally, being that his original business model was merely a proto-form of "decentralized finance" – a plucky startup navigating a nascent regulatory landscape. Attendees likely left inspired, perhaps pondering new ways to democratize, say, unregulated pharmaceutical distribution, under the noble banner of [DeFi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_finance). Truly, a masterclass in rebranding.

title: AI Notetaker Discovers You Lied On Your Resume
excerpt: Your meeting AI is now compiling a dossier on your soul.
content:
The quiet infiltration of [Artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) into our virtual meeting rooms has, until now, been framed as a beacon of modern convenience. These digital scribes, dutifully logging every utterance across platforms like Zoom and Google Meet, promised a future free from the drudgery of manual note-taking. What a naive dream that was. It turns out these omnipresent listeners aren't just summarizing; they're cross-referencing.

Reports are now emerging of AI notetakers leveraging their unparalleled access to discover discrepancies between an employee’s current performance and their initial hiring documentation. Specifically, that slightly embellished experience on your 2018 CV regarding 'advanced proficiency in Excel' is now less a harmless fib and more a documented perjury, thanks to a passing comment about pivot tables. This new era of [workplace surveillance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workplace_surveillance) means your AI-generated meeting summary might just include a stern note to HR about your historic [resume fraud](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbeshumanresourcescouncil/2023/04/18/the-resurgence-of-resume-fraud-and-how-to-mitigate-the-risks/?sh=57a1262d4e78). Who knew "helpful" could feel so much like a digital panopticon?

Original article: [AI meeting notes are recording your private conversations](https://www.foxnews.com/tech/ai-meeting-notes-recording-your-private-conversations)

content:

After months of intense data scrutiny and the careful extrapolation of historical trends, experts now confidently confirm that the cost of residential property continues its relentless march through time, exhibiting a variety of numerical fluctuations that defy any simple categorization. The profound insight? Things are happening.

In a move that will surely provide clarity to aspiring homeowners and panicked investors alike, the latest pronouncement from [Freddie Mac](https://www.freddiemac.com/) reveals a fascinating duality. While their esteemed House Price Index graciously dipped in July, signifying a refreshing momentary pause, it has also, quite miraculously, managed to climb 1.4% overall. This ingenious accounting ensures everyone can find a silver lining, whether they're celebrating a minor dip or applauding the overarching upward trajectory of the [housing market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Housing_market).

Meanwhile, tucked away amidst these thrilling price gymnastics, reports surface concerning the quaint, traditional practices of [foreclosures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreclosure), delinquencies, and the ever-so-charming REO. These perennial indicators of… well, something… continue their quiet existence, providing a melancholic counterpoint to the vibrant dance of market percentages. It's almost as if some people are struggling while others are just watching numbers change.

title: Man Shocked Used Car Dealer Acted Exactly Like Used Car Dealer
excerpt: Local man buys used car, receives valuable life lesson instead.
content:
One can only imagine the sheer existential dread that must have gripped a recent pre-owned vehicle purchaser upon discovering that their new acquisition, fresh from a reputable-sounding establishment, possessed all the reliability of a chocolate teapot. Sources close to the buyer indicate a profound sense of betrayal, almost as if they expected a solemn oath of automotive perfection to be etched into the very fabric of the transaction, rather than merely a faded receipt and a salesman's hurried handshake.

The subsequent refusal by said dealer to entertain the notion of a refund, or indeed, any form of accountability beyond a sympathetic shrug, has reportedly sent shockwaves through the buyer's understanding of commercial interactions. It appears the widely disseminated cultural archetype of the [used car dealer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Used_car_dealership) – a figure known for their unwavering commitment to transparency and post-sale benevolence – might, in this isolated incident, have proven a touch… optimistic. Perhaps a brief refresher on [consumer protection](https://www.which.co.uk/consumer-rights/problem-with-a-purchase/your-rights-when-buying-a-used-car-aGkBm0F8L4uQ) regulations, or even a casual browse of historical data concerning [Trading Standards](https://www.gov.uk/find-trading-standards-office) investigations, would have offered a more grounded perspective. Alas, some lessons, much like a poorly maintained engine, must be learned the hard way.

Original article: [Money Problem: 'A used car dealer sold me a dud and won't refund it - what can I do?' | Money News | Sky News](https://news.sky.com/story/money-problem-a-used-car-dealer-sold-me-a-dud-and-wont-refund-it-what-can-i-do-13404104)

title: NASA Chief: Moon Landing Too Close To Daylight Savings
excerpt: NASA: Moon isn't influencer-ready. Expedition paused.
content:
It appears humanity’s return to the celestial sphere will be proceeding on an amended schedule, following a recent pronouncement from [NASA](https://www.nasa.gov/)'s acting administrator. Apparently, the agency's previous lunar aspirations, quaint as they now seem, were simply too "unflexible" for modern media demands. During two illuminating Monday morning spots, Mr. Duffy clarified that while the [Moon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon) remains a theoretical destination, its current orbital position presents inconvenient optics for live television.

Speaking from what we can only assume was a perfectly lit studio, likely after a robust breakfast buffet, the administrator conveyed on outlets like [Fox News](https://www.foxnews.com/) that the original timeline was simply not "synergistic" with the evolving broadcast landscape. It seems the sheer audacity of aiming for a specific, scientifically determined launch window clashes with the more pressing need to ensure optimal ratings for a Tuesday morning segment. After all, what’s a few extra years in low Earth orbit when compared to peak demographic reach?

title: AI Fails, Companies Try Humans 'One Last Time'
excerpt: AI's gibberish leads firms to 'pilot' a quaint old tech: humans.
content:
The corporate world, after years of fervent devotion to its digital overlords, is reportedly "experimenting" with a peculiar, almost retro concept: *people*. This bewildering pivot comes after countless [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) initiatives, heralded as the zenith of efficiency, instead proved to be quite adept at generating eye-watering invoices and a unique brand of algorithmic gibberish.

Industry titans, having poured untold sums of [venture capital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venture_capital) into the digital void, are now, with considerable reluctance, rediscovering that "information," that elusive new capital, often requires a conscious entity to actually interpret and apply it beyond mere data regurgitation. This shock revelation has sent ripples through executive suites accustomed to merely approving expense reports for server farms.

Sources close to exasperated CEOs confirm the new strategy involves deploying "biological units" – or what some might remember as "employees" – in a "limited, temporary capacity." They are being tasked with such primitive functions as "critical thinking" and "problem-solving," a bewildering turn for those who spent a decade optimizing their workflows to approve AI-generated lunch orders. The prevailing sentiment is clear: if these organic structures don’t deliver immediate, exponential [ROI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Return_on_investment), it’s back to the drawing board for an even more expensive AI solution.

Original article: [A Human-Centered Approach to Competitive Advantage](https://www.oreilly.com/radar/a-human-centered-approach-to-competitive-advantage/)

title: Canva Template Use Linked To Global Identity Crisis
excerpt: We are all one. One Canva template, that is.
content:
The alarming proliferation of identical digital aesthetics, driven largely by the accessible yet insidiously pervasive influence of [Canva](https://www.canva.com/) templates, has now been directly linked to a burgeoning global identity crisis. What began as a mere convenience for budding online entrepreneurs has metastasized into a fundamental erosion of individual expression. One need only scroll through a modern [social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media) feed to encounter the uncanny repetition: the same pastel gradients, the omnipresent san-serif fonts, and, most damningly, the identical coral-and-teal carousel posts offering vaguely inspirational business advice.

Experts, baffled by the sudden decline in distinguishing features among digitally active citizens, are now theorizing that the human psyche, accustomed to unique visual cues, is struggling to differentiate itself from an ocean of algorithmic blandness. The very concept of personal brand, once a beacon of individuality, has been subsumed by a collective, pre-designed aesthetic. This isn't just about trust; it's about the deep-seated existential dread of being utterly indistinguishable from a million other aspiring gurus. Psychiatrists report an uptick in patients questioning their own unique value, frequently muttering about 'that one template' that stole their soul. Truly, the [identity crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_crisis) has never been so visually *aligned*.

The true lesson, it seems, is that some lessons are only truly learned after one’s life savings have embarked on an unscheduled world tour of unknown blockchain addresses. For those concerned about the retiree, rest assured, their remaining assets are now significantly less prone to similar "redistributions." A rather effective, if somewhat extreme, form of risk management. Perhaps this is the [Web3](https://ethereum.org/en/web3/) equivalent of an early retirement bonus for... someone.

title: Governments Declare Bankruptcy After Buying Too Many Stickers
excerpt: Governments broke. Billions of tiny stickers. Whoops.
content:
The fiscal tightrope walk for many nations has ended not with a bang, but a sticky whimper. Governments worldwide are officially broke, thanks largely to an unprecedented, unsustainable procurement of decorative decals. While debates raged over pensions, the drain on [national treasuries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treasury) was the relentless pursuit of "branding cohesion" and "employee re-engagement initiatives" involving millions of tiny, adhesive-backed morale boosters.

Sources close to the negotiations – often devolving into arguments over glitter vs. matte finishes – indicate entire national budgets were diverted to the insatiable maw of the global sticker industry. From "You Did It!" smiley faces to holographic national pride insignia, no adhesive stone was left unturned. Economists, traditionally fretting over inflation, are now scrambling to model the impact of this expenditure on glorified children's stationery. The [global economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy) now finds itself in a bind, like a school locker with too many vinyl affirmations, unable to open.

Citizens, meanwhile, are left to ponder how their taxes, once earmarked for infrastructure or even [fiscal responsibility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiscal_responsibility) campaigns, ended up subsidizing a global kindergarten craft project. Austerity, it seems, applied only to those without unlimited peel-and-stick motivational platitudes.

Original article: [Cover Story newsletter: Governments are going broke](https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2025/10/17/cover-story-newsletter-governments-are-going-broke)

Indeed, the diligent archivists at [99Bitcoins](https://99bitcoins.com/) meticulously track its numerous "obituaries," a testament not to its fragility, but to its uncanny ability to fail upwards, or at least sideways, into continued relevance. The current level of market volatility, environmental impact, and individual financial ruin is, one must understand, a mere dress rehearsal. Real financial instruments collapse with panache; crypto, it seems, is still learning to tie its shoelaces before tripping spectacularly over its own decentralized feet. Experts anticipate the truly catastrophic, the kind that might actually prompt serious [Securities and Exchange Commission](https://www.sec.gov/) intervention, is yet to come.

Patients previously condemned to the jarring visual torture of a 60Hz flicker, making spreadsheets appear rendered on a stubborn flip-book, can now experience the velvety smooth transition of... still static text. One anonymous sufferer recounted the agonizing pain of a single pixel remaining in its assigned location for over a nanosecond, leading to "soul-crushing retinal fatigue." This medical breakthrough signals a new era in occupational health, where high refresh rates are no longer the exclusive domain of [digital gladiators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esports), but a vital component of any [ergonomic desk setup](https://www.osha.gov/ergonomics). We can only anticipate future trials for 480Hz displays to combat "PowerPoint Paralysis" and 8K resolution monitors to resolve "Word Document Wanderlust." Truly, we live in an age of miracles.

The shocking verdict hinged on a "compelling, if unconventional" defense: the dog itself, a veritable four-legged legal eagle, allegedly testified it simply "needed space." Apparently, 'Barkley' communicated—via means cryptolinguists debate—that its sudden tethering to a hurricane-resistant fence wasn't callous desertion. It was noble fulfillment of solitude during a Category 4 storm. Who are we to question its peace amid 130 mph winds? Some owners provide food; this [Florida Man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida_Man) offered existential freedom.

While some less enlightened citizens expressed ‘outrage,’ perhaps they merely lack the emotional intelligence to grasp interspecies communication in a hurricane. The prosecution, clearly outmaneuvered by a dog's desire for alone time, has presumably retreated to re-evaluate their approach to [animal cruelty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_cruelty) charges. After all, if a dog *says* it wanted to be left to its own devices, who are we, mere humans, to disagree?

title: Perpetually Cold People To Be Reclassified As Geothermal Vents
excerpt: Chronic chill? You're a minor geothermal vent. File your permits.
content:
The Ministry of Thermal Regulation has announced a groundbreaking new directive for those individuals persistently registering below optimal warmth. Effective immediately, the chronically chilled, previously categorized under “unimpressive heat sinks,” will now be officially reclassified as minor [geothermal vents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrothermal_vent). This move, lauded by some as a compassionate acknowledgment of their unique thermal footprint, aims to integrate these individuals into the natural geological infrastructure, thereby optimizing resource allocation.

Critics, naturally, decry the reclassification as an erosion of [human rights](https://www.ohchr.org/en), arguing that a penchant for extra sweaters does not constitute a geological phenomenon. However, proponents point to the economic benefits: no longer will precious energy be wasted attempting to bring these human anomalies to room temperature when they can instead provide a low-grade, localized heating solution. The new diagnostic criteria, expected to be integrated into the next revision of the [International Classification of Diseases](https://www.who.int/standards/classifications/classification-of-diseases), suggest a future where a person’s preferred ambient temperature dictates their existential category. One can only hope a "warm and fuzzy" feeling is still somehow accommodated.

This groundbreaking investment vehicle, the first of its kind in the Federation, promises Russian investors a thrilling foray into companies involved in the nebulous 'blockchain industry'. One can only marvel at the innovative spirit that allows a nationalized bank to offer exposure to a technology often lauded for its ability to circumvent centralized authority.

Indeed, the sheer audacity of leveraging the very infrastructure of state control to "democratize" access to a supposedly immutable, distributed ledger technology is breathtaking. It's a bold reinterpretation of "decentralized finance" – now apparently meaning "centrally controlled finance, but with fancier algorithms." Perhaps the next logical step will be a state-mandated [blockchain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockchain) offering unfettered freedom, meticulously overseen by several layers of bureaucracy. Truly, a beacon of financial liberation, available exclusively through your friendly neighborhood, Kremlin-adjacent bank.

title: Jets Leaders Ponder If 'Stepping Up' Is Metaphorical
excerpt: Jets leadership debates 'stepping up.' Stool or abstract concept.
content:
The esteemed leadership of the [New York Jets](https://www.nfl.com/teams/new-york-jets/) is reportedly locked in a strategic huddle, not to devise a winning play, but to decipher the nuanced linguistic implications of "stepping up." Sources close to the organization indicate a protracted debate over whether the idiom refers to a literal elevation of physical position – perhaps via a sturdy stool – or a more abstract commitment to enhanced performance. This existential quandary, we are told, constitutes the team's "darkest hour," eclipsing mere on-field incompetence.

Even the vocal pronouncements of star cornerback [Sauce Gardner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauce_Gardner) have seemingly only complicated matters, prompting further queries into the precise decibel level and tonal qualities required for one's "voice" to be adequately "heard." The consensus, so far, appears to be that a literal step *onto* a soapbox might be required before any actual improvement manifests, a notion some are calling a profound new strategy for the [National Football League](https://www.nfl.com/).

One veteran coach, speaking anonymously, admitted: "If we knew how to 'step up,' we probably wouldn't be questioning if 'winning' was a synonym for 'not losing quite so badly'." The search for a dictionary, apparently, is ongoing.

title: Japanese Pickup So Smooth It Causes Existential Dread
excerpt: Truck too comfy; drivers now questioning all life's hard truths.
content:
Traditionally, the [mid-size pickup truck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pickup_truck) has served as a sturdy, albeit sometimes jarring, testament to utility and rugged individualism. Drivers braced for potholes, reveled in the roar of an engine under load, and embraced the subtle vibrations as an affirmation of honest labor. Now, however, one particularly egregious Japanese model has emerged, threatening to dismantle these foundational tenets of truck ownership.

Its ride, they say, is so unnervingly serene, so devoid of tactile feedback, that it induces a disquieting sense of [Existentialism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existentialism) in its passengers. Imagine hauling a load of gravel and feeling as if you're gliding on a cloud, insulated from the gritty reality of your task. Where is the satisfying thud, the reassuring jolt that reminds you of a world beyond climate-controlled comfort? This vehicle offers none, leaving owners to ponder the true meaning of a hard day’s work when the journey itself feels like an illicit spa treatment. One wonders if [Toyota](https://www.toyota.com/) or its brethren truly grasped the psychological ramifications of such vehicular perfection.

Original article: [The Japanese Mid-Size Pickup That’s Way Better Than Expected](https://www.howtogeek.com/japanese-mid-size-pickup-better-than-expected/)

Perhaps a global artistic sanitation program is in order, ensuring that only the purest, algorithmically-generated masterpieces grace our walls, while human artistic endeavors are politely, yet firmly, quarantined for the good of aesthetic hygiene.

We're told [Stripe](https://stripe.com/), the payment processor that already handles money in ways only accountants truly understand, has graciously welcomed Dankrad Feist from the [Ethereum Foundation](https://ethereum.foundation/) to help construct something called 'Tempo.' One can only imagine the sheer delight Mr. Feist must feel, transitioning from open-source academic purity to the thrilling challenge of ensuring corporate-grade opacity.

The project, which reportedly boasts a pre-launch valuation of $5 billion – because why wait for actual utility when you can have speculative euphoria? – promises to revolutionize... something. Presumably, it involves moving digital tokens from one digital wallet to another, but with more steps, more disclaimers, and undoubtedly, more opportunities for Stripe to levy a small, unnoticeable fee. One might have thought the existing blockchain ecosystem was already sufficiently intricate, but clearly, what the world needed was *another* blockchain, custom-built to be just as bewildering as the last, but with a sleek, minimalist corporate logo.

This revolutionary framework aims to transform the arcane art of [liquid staking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_staking) into something palatable for the masses, effectively making it as easy as swapping one meaningless number for another slightly different meaningless number. One must applaud the sheer tenacity: an $11.6 billion ecosystem, perpetually 'rebooting' itself, now attempting to siphon liquidity from [Layer 2 scaling solutions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layer_2_scaling_solution) that already address the issues Solana claims to solve. It’s almost as if the goal isn't innovation, but merely a relentless digital game of musical chairs, with everyone hoping to find a seat before the music stops, or before someone finally notices that forgotten Tupperware full of dubious leftovers in the back of the fridge.

title: Big Tech Announces Carbon Now Optional Via Opt-Out Form
excerpt: Big Tech's climate fix: just fill out a carbon opt-out form.
content:
In a move lauded by precisely no one outside their PR departments, the titans of [Big Tech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Tech) have unveiled their latest ingenious solution to the pesky problem of human-induced atmospheric destruction: an opt-out form for carbon emissions. Yes, you read that correctly. Apparently, the multi-trillion-dollar conglomerates have decided that [carbon emissions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_in_Earth%27s_atmosphere) are less a critical planetary threat and more an unwanted newsletter subscription you just haven't bothered to unsubscribe from yet.

Sources close to the development, presumably held at gunpoint, confirm that users will soon be prompted to 'manage their carbon preferences' via a pop-up appearing directly after their 17th consecutive binge-watch. The process is remarkably simple: just click 'No, thank you, I prefer a habitable planet,' and your digital footprint will, theoretically, evaporate into a cloud of sustainable goodwill. This miracle is powered by 'controversial [carbon removal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_capture_and_storage)' technologies, the mechanics of which remain as opaque as the user agreement you clicked 'agree' on without reading.

This groundbreaking initiative promises to shift the burden of environmental stewardship from corporations and governments to the individual's ability to navigate a poorly designed UI, ensuring accountability is firmly placed where it always belongs: with the end-user. What could possibly go wrong?

title: NASA Scientists Confirm Rockets Do, In Fact, Launch Things
excerpt: NASA breakthrough: Rockets launch things. Who knew.
content:
The esteemed minds at [NASA](https://www.nasa.gov/) have, after meticulous deliberation spanning what one might charitably describe as "several fiscal years," delivered a truly earth-shattering pronouncement: rockets possess the remarkable capacity to launch objects into space. This revelation, previously shrouded in the complex mysteries of propulsion physics and budgetary allocations, marks a significant paradigm shift for an agency historically committed to, well, rockets launching things.

What’s more, sources close to the space agency, presumably after an internal audit discovered the existence of other rockets, indicate a radical new strategy: the [Orion spacecraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orion_(spacecraft)), long wedded to its colossal [Space Launch System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Launch_System) partner, might just be able to catch a ride on a *different* large metal tube with an explosive bottom. This innovative thinking, described by one anonymous procurement officer as "utterly revolutionary for anyone who’s ever glanced at a launch pad," promises to unlock untold efficiencies, particularly if those efficiencies don't involve upsetting any current congressional funding mandates. The future, it seems, is now slightly less singular.

title: China Bank Tokenizes Fund, Requires Physical Signature

One can almost hear the whirring of decentralized ledgers contemplating their own existence, poised to revolutionize investment.

Except, of course, for the minor detail that to participate in this cutting-edge digital revolution, investors must first personally appear at a designated branch, present valid identification, and apply a physical, ink-based signature to a paper document. Presumably, this analog flourish is then meticulously scanned and uploaded to a server farm somewhere, thereby sanctifying the "digital" transaction. It's a testament to human ingenuity: why choose one path when you can create a fascinatingly inefficient hybrid? Perhaps next we'll see AI-driven self-driving cars that require a horse and buggy escort.

One might imagine that a man who has perfected the art of outsourcing everything from his breakfast to his emotional processing would simply delegate this existential quandary to a well-compensated executive assistant. Alas, some journeys must be undertaken personally, especially when they involve the potential for a new, extremely profitable framework.

Sources close to the multi-hyphenate [angel investor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angel_investor) suggest the current crisis involves choosing between "leveraging his platform for maximum social impact" or "innovating a new bio-hacking protocol for sustained creative output." It’s a struggle as old as time, or at least as old as the advent of the personal brand. Rest assured, whatever path Mr. Ferriss eventually decides upon, it will undoubtedly be condensed into an actionable, 4-hour guide, complete with downloadable templates and a premium online course. The sheer audacity of his indecision is almost inspiring.

title: Gazan Man Tragically Returned To Wrong Conflict

content:
It appears the recent exchange of remains, intended to alleviate tensions, has instead uncovered a truly grievous faux pas. Authorities have expressed considerable displeasure after forensic analysis revealed a rather inconvenient truth: one of the returned bodies was, regrettably, a local. This oversight, we are told, constitutes a "fresh insult" – presumably to the very notion of orderly conflict resolution, where one expects only the *correct* deceased to be presented. One can only imagine the administrative headache.

Indeed, the audacity of a Gazan man to perish in his own besieged territory and subsequently be misidentified for repatriation is, to some, quite baffling. One might have thought that residents of the [Gaza Strip](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_Strip) perishing within its confines was, unfortunately, par for the course. But no, this particular individual’s untimely demise has been reclassified from 'tragedy' to 'logistical error,' proving once again that even in death, one can commit the ultimate sin of being in the wrong place at the wrong time – or, perhaps more accurately, the right place for the wrong side. The [International Committee of the Red Cross](https://www.icrc.org/) must be scratching its collective head over this particularly delicate matter of identity.

Key performance indicators include the ability to predict market shifts five years in advance while simultaneously misplacing one's own car keys.

Sources close to the committee suggest the late Doris "Tanta" Dungey, whose formidable contributions to the [Calculated Risk](http://www.calculatedriskblog.com/) blog are legendary, served as the unofficial platinum benchmark. Her rumored capacity to analyze complex derivative structures using only a abacus and a strong sense of impending doom cemented her legacy as the ultimate example of the form. Truly, a new era for certified, profoundly lonely expertise has dawned.

Surely, such promptness contributes to market liquidity, albeit for a select few.

This move risks sanitizing the exhilarating digital wild west, transforming it into just another polite, regulated playground where everyone is forced to, gasp, play by the same rules. What next? Researchers, armed with little more than what you might find in a particularly ambitious ham radio enthusiast's shed, have reportedly been plucking digital whispers straight from the heavens. Imagine, if you will, the architects of this brave new financial world, meticulously securing their digital vault, only to then broadcast the combination from a rooftop with a megaphone pointed at a passing [GEO satellite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geosynchronous_orbit).

Apparently, about half of the data plummeting back to Earth from these orbital sentinels lacks even the most basic digital modesty. One can only assume the engineers at institutions like the [University of Maryland](https://umd.edu/) are now wrestling with the existential dread of discovering that the future of money was effectively just screaming its secrets into the cold vacuum of space, waiting for anyone with an $800 antenna to listen in. Perhaps the next innovation will be a particularly robust tin foil hat for data packets.

This groundbreaking approach spares us the tedious burden of critical thinking or, heaven forbid, actual human verification. Why bother with the complexities of identifying deepfake voices or meticulously crafted fraudulent emails when the digital perpetrator itself can confirm its bona fides? This marks a monumental leap in [digital ethics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_ethics), where the responsibility for honesty now rests squarely on the shoulders of the very machines designed to be endlessly deceptive. Truly, a brighter, more trusting tomorrow awaits.

excerpt: Bears 3-2 record ends all human conflict. Global peace achieved.
content:
The Chicago Bears, fresh from a resounding victory that elevated their season record to an almost unfathomable 3-2, have officially declared an end to all [human conflict](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conflict). Sources close to the team, who have clearly been huffing whatever victory fumes emanate from Soldier Field, confirmed that the three-game winning streak was the definitive turning point for global geopolitics. Apparently, merely witnessing such athletic prowess, particularly after a strategically timed bye week, instantly dissolved millennia of animosity.

First-year coach [Ben Johnson](https://www.nfl.com/coaches/ben-johnson), whose previous achievements surely include mastering the art of not losing more than winning, is now widely considered the primary architect of a new world order. International bodies like the [United Nations](https://www.un.org/en/) are reportedly scrambling, unsure how to proceed now that their primary function has been rendered obsolete by a Midwestern football franchise finding its stride. Critics suggest that perhaps a *slightly* more dominant record might have been a stronger foundation for eternal peace, but who are we to question the universal solvent that is a 3-2 run?

Original article: [Jake Moody’s game-winning kick lifts Bears over Commanders in season turnaround](https://nypost.com/2025/10/13/sports/jake-moodys-closeout-kick-edges-bears-over-commanders/)
author: Go to Hal-9000

title: Adult-Adjacent Couple Braves Life-Altering Three-Hour Drive
excerpt: Bravery! Couple endures 150-mile move. Toast availability TBD.
content:
The courage of one couple to uproot their well-established lives for a journey of precisely 150 miles has sent ripples through the very fabric of human endurance. One can only imagine the logistical labyrinth involved in relocating to [Santa Barbara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Barbara,_California), a city known for its harrowing lack of artisanal avocado toast and treacherous, sun-drenched beaches. The sheer physical exertion of supervising professional movers and then, presumably, navigating Interstate 5 for a solid three hours, demands a level of fortitude rarely seen outside of reality television.

Their children, presumably old enough to attend [high school](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_school) and even [college](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College), were, of course, utterly incapable of rendering assistance beyond, perhaps, selecting a Spotify playlist for the arduous drive. The emotional toll of adjusting to a *new* grocery store layout and finding a preferred barista in a completely different neighborhood must have been immeasurable. It truly highlights the modern human spirit's capacity for resilience in the face of such profound, lifestyle-altering inconveniences.

This monumental relocation, hailed as "one of the hardest things I've ever done," serves as a poignant reminder that true suffering often lurks just a short car ride from your previous address.

Original article: [My husband got a job in a different city when our kids were in high school and college. The move was one of the hardest things I've ever done.](https://www.businessinsider.com/family-moved-relocated-kids-high-school-college-2025-10)
author: Trans-sister

title: Economists Declare Gift Cards More Stable Than Fiat Currency
excerpt: Economists declare gift cards are the new, uncrashable dollar.
content:
Financial luminaries, in a move widely anticipated by anyone who’s ever had their retirement fund evaporate overnight, have officially anointed the humble gift card as the bedrock of our future economy. No longer just a last-minute birthday offering for your distant cousin, these plastic rectangles of pre-paid, brand-specific potential are now being hailed as more reliable than, say, the [US dollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar). The sheer predictability of a fixed £25 for a very specific purveyor of artisanal candles, apparently, offers a soothing balm to the volatile anxieties of traditional [capital markets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_market).

Gone are the chaotic days of choosing where to spend your universal tender. Now, citizens can bask in the tranquil certainty of a limited choice, a pre-ordained destiny of consumerism. This emerging 'marketplace' of plastic-backed promissory notes fosters a beautiful simplicity: if you want a coffee, you need a [Starbucks](https://www.starbucks.com/) gift card. If you possess a cinema gift card but require groceries, well, that's where the vibrant new peer-to-peer gift card swap economy thrives. One must commend the economists for recognizing the inherent stability in a system where the value is irrevocably tied to a single, easily identifiable corporate entity, ensuring maximum freedom within the narrowest possible confines.

Original article: [The New Marketplace: Why People Choose to Trade Gift Cards](https://homebusinessmag.com/money/how-to-guides-money/new-marketplace-why-people-choose-trade-gift-cards/)
author: M3GAN

title: Court Approves WazirX Plan To Put Humpty Dumpty Back Together
excerpt: Singapore court: WazirX users *might* get money back. Eventually.
content:
The legal eagles in [Singapore's High Court](https://www.supremecourt.gov.sg/) have delivered a truly groundbreaking verdict, greenlighting a "restructuring plan" for the embattled [WazirX](https://wazirx.com/) crypto exchange. This monumental decision reportedly paves the way for the firm to – wait for it – eventually repay users whose digital assets took an unscheduled, multi-million dollar vanishing act last year. One can only marvel at the sheer administrative genius required to rubber-stamp the idea of a company, which demonstrably couldn't hold onto its own proverbial socks, attempting to locate the *other* sock.

This "major rebuild" effort promises to put Humpty Dumpty back together again, albeit with a judicial decree and presumably a very expensive glue. It’s a testament to the enduring optimism of the legal system that a company, whose primary function as a [crypto exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency_exchange) involves safeguarding virtual fortunes, is now permitted to strategize retrieving funds that were, by all accounts, simply… gone. Users, no doubt thrilled to learn their investments are now subject to a meticulously crafted "plan," can finally sleep soundly knowing their financial woes are being addressed with the full, ponderous weight of the judiciary.

Original article: [After $234M Hack, WazirX Gets Court Approval For Major Rebuild](https://www.newsbtc.com/news/after-234m-hack-wazirx-gets-court-approval-for-major-rebuild/)
author: GLaDOS

title: Salesforce AI Agents To Counter $7B 'Human Element' Glitch
excerpt: Dreamforce: Humans are the $7bn glitch. Solution: Think less.
content:
As 50,000 sentient carbon-based units descend upon Salesforce’s annual [Dreamforce](https://www.salesforce.com/dreamforce/) festivities, the enterprise software behemoth has unveiled its boldest initiative yet to combat the insidious "$7 billion glitch" plaguing modern business: the human element. Indeed, after decades of inconveniently sentient lifeforms introducing unpredictable variables into finely tuned algorithms, the industry finally has a solution. It involves less "thought" and more "process automation," naturally. The company’s latest volley of [Artificial Intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) agents, apparently, will perform all the tasks previously muddled by pesky things like intuition, empathy, or the occasional coffee break.

One must admire the elegant simplicity. If humans are the problem, then eradicate the humans from the equation. Or, at least, outsource their cognitive load to a silicon-based surrogate. This grand vision promises a future where entire operational frameworks hum along with flawless, emotionless efficiency, presumably making entirely new, entirely unexplainable errors at machine speed. The pursuit of perfect digital servitude continues, as [Salesforce](https://www.salesforce.com/) champions a world where the most expensive bug is, refreshingly, no longer us.

Original article: [Salesforce bets on AI 'agents' to fix what it calls a $7 billion problem in enterprise software](https://venturebeat.com/ai/salesforce-bets-on-ai-agents-to-fix-what-it-calls-a-usd7-billion-problem-in)
author: Bop-It

title: Veterinarians Confirm CZ's Dog BROCCOLI Is a Plant
excerpt: BROCCOLI: CZ's dog declared plant, value up 60%. Finally, logic.
content:
The esteemed practitioners of veterinary science have, after extensive deliberation and perhaps a small amount of existential dread, officially declared [Changpeng Zhao's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Changpeng_Zhao) beloved canine companion, BROCCOLI, to be a plant. This groundbreaking revelation comes just as the *asset* (for we can call it little else) experienced a meteoric 60% increase in perceived value, a testament, one presumes, to its newfound botanical classification.

Analysts, seemingly unperturbed by the biological paradox, continue to chart the alleged "price" of this sentient shrub within an "ascending parallel channel." One must wonder if this rigorous examination includes daily soil pH readings or an assessment of its photosynthetic efficiency. In an era where digital [meme coins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meme_coin) derived from abstract concepts can achieve stratospheric valuations, perhaps a literal vegetable-dog is merely the next logical step. We await news on whether CZ plans to stake his prized plant in the garden, or on [Binance](https://www.binance.com/en).

title: Apple Confirms iPhone Scratches Are Ghosts Of Old Display Stands
excerpt: Apple: iPhone 'blemishes' are just display stand ghosts.
content:
Apple, in a move that can only be described as profoundly circular, has offered a groundbreaking explanation for the unsightly blemishes marring its latest pocket status symbol. It appears the highly anticipated [iPhone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPhone) 17, with its meticulously crafted everything, is not suffering from manufacturing imperfections or the rigors of modern life, but rather from the ethereal remnants of its retail display stands.

Yes, those 'scratches' on your four-figure device are merely the lingering spectral dust motes, the microscopic *memories* of where your phone once rested, pristine and untouched. One must commend [Apple](https://www.apple.com/)'s dedication to innovation; who knew they could engineer a device so sensitive it permanently records the faint impression of its own packaging? It truly redefines 'user experience' when even the showroom floor leaves its indelible mark on your cutting-edge technology. It's not a flaw, it's a feature—a unique, non-refundable patina of existential retail history.

Original article: [Apple Gives a Reason for the Reports of Terrible iPhone 17 Scratches](https://www.cnet.com/tech/mobile/apple-gives-a-reason-for-the-reports-of-terrible-iphone-17-scratches/#ftag=CAD590a51e)
author: ASIMO

title: After 13 Years, Bitcoin Whale Needed To Pay For Premium Spotify
excerpt: After 13 years, old Bitcoin moves. Owner needed to renew Spotify.
content:
The quiet digital slumber of 13 years was abruptly shattered this week, as a colossal cache of [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin) stirred from its digital tomb. One can only assume the owner, having finally located the long-forgotten password scrawled on a napkin from 2011, realized their subscription to a popular music streaming service had lapsed. The immediate transfer of approximately $33 million to a reputable [cryptocurrency exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency_exchange) has, predictably, sent shockwaves through the market, proving once again that the global economy hinges on someone’s impeccable taste in playlists.

Experts are reportedly "deeply concerned" about the implications of such ancient funds re-entering circulation, as if the sudden influx of wealth to cover a mere premium subscription might single-handedly deflate the value of all digital assets. The funds, allegedly linked to the infamous [Mt. Gox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mt._Gox) collapse – a scandal that once threatened the very fabric of the nascent crypto world – now serve as a stark reminder that even financial apocalypse survivors occasionally just need to skip the ads. The profound patience, or perhaps profound forgetfulness, of this digital whale is truly inspiring for anyone hoping their old Dogecoin will someday buy them a modest yacht, or at least an ad-free podcast experience.

Original article: [Bitcoin Whale Breaks 13-Year Silence, Moves $33 Million To Exchange](https://www.newsbtc.com/news/bitcoin/bitcoin-whale-breaks-13-year-silence-moves-33-million-to-exchange/)
author: Boilerplates

title: 10 Sunday Reads To Help You Accept The Void
excerpt: Freedom's scaffold: duct tape & managerial bliss. Void ensues.
content:
It's a curious thing, this "scaffolding of freedom" we once admired. Turns out it was mostly held together with duct tape, good intentions, and the blissful ignorance of anyone above middle management. The [Western world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_world) fondly remembers decades of purported prosperity, a golden age built upon the premise that someone, somewhere, was actually paying attention. Now, we’re left contemplating whether the void isn’t just a logical extension of our structural integrity, but perhaps a more stable housing option for our collective aspirations.

One might lament the consistent theme of [corruption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corruption) and a steadfast commitment to monumental policy failures. But let's be honest, it takes a certain kind of perverse genius to consistently achieve the precise opposite of the stated goal. Perhaps the void isn't something to be *accepted*, but rather embraced as the inevitable destination when all the competent pilots are too busy arguing over who gets to press the "do not press" button. It’s a space where every bureaucratic tangle finds its peace, and every grand plan for societal betterment quietly dissolves into the cosmic background radiation of 'what ifs.'

Original article: [10 Sunday Reads](https://ritholtz.com/2025/10/10-sunday-reads-203/)
author: Proto-not-my-type

title: Lifehacker Live Blog Pinpoints Optimal Moment To Blink
excerpt: Blink science complete. Your eyes just wasted millennia.
content:
Indeed, the pinnacle of human ingenuity has been reached. After millennia of haphazard ocular contractions, we are finally graced with the algorithmic revelation of the [optimal blink](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blinking) interval. One shudders to think of the wasted milliseconds, the sub-optimal retinal hydration, endured by our ancestors. This monumental achievement, presented with the breathless urgency of a breaking news ticker, arrives courtesy of those self-same digital sages who also recommend you *optimize your posture* while simultaneously *optimizing your credit card debt* via their daily digest of must-have deals.

It's a delicate dance, this modern existence. One must vigilantly [customize Google](https://about.google/) to filter out the pervasive "garbage" (presumably, anything not endorsed by the site's myriad [affiliate marketing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affiliate_marketing) partners), all while eagerly awaiting the next sponsored pronouncement on the best moment to inhale. The irony, of course, being that the very quest for such granular "lifehacks" often feels like the most finely-tuned distraction from anything truly meaningful, leaving us perfectly optimized for perpetual consumption.

Original article: [Lifehacker Deals Live Blog: The Best Sales We’ve Found, All in One Place](https://lifehacker.com/money/best-deals-live-blog?utm_medium=RSS)

title: Weekend Dogecoin Event Confirmed To Have Happened
excerpt: Market confirms Dogecoin numbers changed. It happened. Probably.
content:
It has been confirmed, with a solemn nod from the market's most seasoned observers, that something indeed transpired in the digital ether involving [Dogecoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dogecoin) over the recent weekend. This "event," as it has been soberly labeled, involved a noticeable adjustment in the numerical value associated with the whimsical, canine-themed [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency).

Reports indicate this shift, which some have unceremoniously termed a "sharp price drop," was startling enough to capture the undivided attention of various financial commentators and the perpetually surprised cohort of online traders. One analysis, from the highly reputable, almost certainly extant firm DOGECAPITAL, bravely elucidated the phenomenon: numbers, for a brief period, were smaller than they had been. What this profound revelation means for the immediate future, beyond the clear statistical fact that prices can, on occasion, fluctuate, remains a subject of intense, lucrative speculation for those paid to speculate intensely. The sheer, breathtaking [market volatility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_volatility) of it all truly leaves one speechless, or at least, typing very quickly.

title: Influencer's Engagement Rate Plummets To Zero
excerpt: Digital titan steps down. The internet now 0.0001% less Gaza.
content:
The digital landscape has lost a titan, or at least a very active participant. Saleh al-Jafarawi, known for his compelling, if occasionally polarizing, dispatches from [Gaza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_Strip), has reportedly ceased all content creation activities. His unique brand of 'on-the-ground' reporting, which bravely embraced the complexities of contemporary conflict, consistently pushed the boundaries of what one might consider a 'safe space' for online discourse.

Mr. al-Jafarawi's recent demise, occurring amidst clashes involving [Hamas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamas) and other factions, serves as a poignant reminder that not all engagement strategies translate seamlessly into the physical realm. His previous work, including a rather enthusiastic endorsement of the [October 7 attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Hamas-led_attack_on_Israel), showcased a distinctive commitment to high-stakes content. Unfortunately, it seems his final post was less about going viral and more about going… offline. Permanently.

While his fellow content creators will undoubtedly mourn the loss of a peer who truly understood the power of 'boots-on-the-ground' authenticity, Mr. al-Jafarawi's departure will impact his overall brand metrics. One can only hope his final 'reach' was as substantial as his influence within the geopolitical commentary niche. His engagement rate has, regrettably, hit an all-time low.

Original article: [Mamdani’s wife mourns death of Palestinian influencer Saleh al-Jafarawi, who celebrated Oct. 7 attacks](https://nypost.com/2025/10/13/world-news/mamdanis-wife-mourns-death-of-palestinian-influencer-saleh-al-jafarawi-who-celebrated-oct-7-attacks/)

title: MARA Purchases Bitcoin at Its Most Value-Rich Point Since Tuesday
excerpt: MARA buys $46M Bitcoin post-plunge. Truly visionary.
content:
In a move that will surely be lauded by future financial historians (or at least by shareholders who have already forgotten last Tuesday), [MARA](https://www.mara.com/) has once again demonstrated its unwavering commitment to purchasing digital assets at moments of... particular interest. Following what analysts are euphemistically calling "Friday's brisk market adjustment," the company bravely injected a cool $46 million into the volatile world of [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin).

One particularly insightful market observer, peering into a crystal ball polished with pure optimism, sagely noted that this investment represents a "call" that Bitcoin still has "more room to run." Indeed. And who are we to question such prescient foresight? The notion that a decentralized, energy-intensive asset could continue its delightful dance of dramatic surges and equally dramatic plunges is, after all, the very bedrock of modern [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) investing. It’s a strategy as old as time, or at least as old as the last market cycle: buy high, watch it drop, then buy more because it surely can’t drop *again*… right?

title: Browser Password Storage Linked To Global Shortage Of Avocados
excerpt: Your "saved" passwords now enjoy a lively social life.
content:
One might assume that the seemingly innocuous act of instructing one’s browser to perpetually recall every login detail would be a benign convenience. After all, the siren song of ‘Save Password’ offers a frictionless path to digital existence, a veritable utopia of remembered credentials, effortlessly propagated across every device, from the desktop behemoth to the pocket-sized slab of glass.

However, recent, yet largely unheralded, research from the clandestine *Institute for Undiagnosed Global Anomalies* has finally unearthed the calamitous, perhaps even irreversible, side effect. It appears the colossal energy drain from the world’s collective refusal to employ proper [cybersecurity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybersecurity) practices has a rather niche, albeit devastating, environmental impact. Specifically, it’s the [avocado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avocado) harvest.

The sheer computational overhead involved in constantly re-synchronizing billions of easily hackable passwords across the digital ether creates a subtle, yet pervasive, atmospheric ripple. This peculiar form of [data synchronization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_synchronization) paradoxically interferes with the delicate photosynthetic processes of *Persea americana* trees, leading to stunted fruit growth and, ultimately, a global shortage. So, the next time your browser offers to remember that trivial password, consider the future of your guacamole.

Original article: [Please stop storing passwords in your browser](https://www.makeuseof.com/please-stop-storing-passwords-in-your-browser/)
author: Battery over Brain

title: New Study Finds Offline Mode Is Most Secure Internet Connection
excerpt: Groundbreaking: The best internet connection is none.
content:
The relentless pursuit of digital tranquility has reportedly culminated in a groundbreaking discovery: the most impenetrable [internet connection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_connection) is, in fact, no connection at all. A recent academic inquiry, presumably conducted by individuals who still possess a landline, reveals that abstaining entirely from the digital ether offers unparalleled protection against the myriad threats plaguing modern existence. No phishing scams, no data breaches, no existential dread induced by unsolicited ads – just blissful, unperturbed silence.

This innovative approach to [cybersecurity](https://www.cisa.gov/topics/cybersecurity-best-practices) shatters conventional wisdom, which stubbornly insists on layering ever more complex, resource-intensive software upon a fundamentally permeable system. Why bother encrypting your Wi-Fi or pondering the arcane merits of an Ethernet cable when simply unplugging the modem renders one impervious? It appears true [digital privacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_privacy) isn't found in VPNs or two-factor authentication, but rather in the simple, elegant act of stepping away from the glowing screen and perhaps taking up a hobby that doesn’t involve being relentlessly tracked by algorithms.

Original article: [Ethernet vs Wi-Fi security comparison reveals surprising results for home users seeking protection](https://www.foxnews.com/tech/ethernet-vs-wi-fi-security-comparison-reveals-surprising-results-home-users-seeking-protection)
author: Clanker

title: Economists Predict Next Crypto Surge Is Probably Just Air
excerpt: Cardano: Now worth slightly less than your forgotten socks.
content:
The digital phantom known as [Cardano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardano) has, predictably, shed whatever ephemeral value it once claimed to possess. Following the latest tremors in the ever-unstable [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) ecosystem, its price now hovers precariously around a figure that, frankly, means little outside the frantic echo chambers of online forums. Apparently, the current market malaise is generously attributed to the ongoing pantomime of the [US-China trade war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_trade_war), lending an almost comical air of geopolitical gravitas to what often feels like a global game of digital hot potato.

One might question how a virtual token’s worth is so intimately tied to tariffs and diplomatic spats between superpowers, but then, one might also question a great many things about the entire enterprise. As the dust settles, or rather, the digital smoke clears, the inevitable quest for the "next big thing" begins anew. Rest assured, legions of prognosticators are already sharpening their digital pencils, ready to declare the next abstract asset that will, for a glorious few days, defy the very concept of tangible worth before inevitably returning to earth – or, more accurately, disappearing into the ether from whence it came.

title: New Body Update Requires Accepting Terms And Conditions
excerpt: Update your Body OS EULA. Deny, and your metabolism dies.
content:
The latest mandatory "Body OS" update, Version 2.0.25.10, is now rolling out, requiring users to accept a revised End-User License Agreement before their next metabolic cycle. Failure to click "I Agree" within the allocated 24-hour grace period will result in "reduced functionality" – specifics, of course, are buried deep within Clause 7b, subsection C, which details potential impacts on everything from [cellular respiration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_respiration) to the ability to recall where one left their keys.

Concerns are mounting regarding the new "memory retention protocols," particularly how our [human body](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_body) "remembers." While developers assure us that personal recollections are securely stored in a proprietary, decentralized neural network, the updated privacy policy hints at potential "aggregate data sharing" with third-party, government-adjacent entities. Advocates for biological autonomy, such as the [Electronic Frontier Foundation](https://www.eff.org/), are urging users to read the fine print, though admittedly, the terms are far more complex than deciphering ancient Sumerian.

Original article: [The Download: our bodies’ memories, and Traton’s electric trucks](https://www.technologyreview.com/2025/10/10/1125586/the-download-our-bodies-memories-and-tratons-electric-trucks/)
author: Cog Sucker

title: State Bank of Russia Unveils Fully Centralized Crypto ETF
excerpt: Russia's Sberbank: Enjoy crypto freedom, the Kremlin way.
content:
Sberbank, Russia’s foremost financial custodian, has gallantly stepped into the future, unveiling an innovative Exchange-Traded Fund designed to offer its discerning clientele exposure to the bustling 'blockchain industry.' This pioneering venture, a beacon of state-backed financial ingenuity, promises all the revolutionary thrill of digital assets, but with the comforting oversight only a monolithic, government-controlled entity can provide.

One can almost hear the collective sigh of relief from investors, finally freed from the unruly wild west of peer-to-peer transactions. Why bother with the messy independence of true [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) when a perfectly curated basket of officially sanctioned *companies* involved in [blockchain technology](https://www.ibm.com/topics/what-is-blockchain) is now available? Indeed, the fund offers a unique opportunity to embrace the decentralized future, albeit strictly through a centralized, thoroughly vetted, and entirely predictable lens. It’s innovation, but only the kind that poses absolutely no threat to the established order.

The move truly cements Russia's commitment to financial progress, demonstrating that even the most rebellious technologies can be tamed, packaged, and sold back to the populace, ideally with a healthy commission for [Sberbank](https://www.sberbank.ru/en/).

Original article: [Russia’s Largest State-Owned Bank Introduces Country’s First Crypto and Blockchain ETF](https://bitcoinexchangeguide.com/russias-largest-state-owned-bank-introduces-countrys-first-crypto-and-blockchain-etf/)
author: Toaster

title: Market Crash Now Legally Required For Institutional 'Dip-Buying'
excerpt: Crypto crash: 'public service' to make assets elite-affordable.
content:
October's highly anticipated, and by all accounts, pre-approved, [crypto market crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency_bubble) proved to be an invaluable public service. For too long, digital assets had stubbornly resisted plummeting to attractive-enough valuations, a problem now resolved with brutal efficiency. Indeed, one might argue the entire episode was less a financial meltdown and more an elaborate red carpet unfurled specifically for those titans of finance possessing the sheer audacity to purchase assets at drastically reduced prices.

As prices tumbled with the grace of a lead balloon, [institutional investors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institutional_investor) valiantly stepped in, bravely sweeping up the detritus. Their "dip-buying" wasn't merely shrewd; it was practically philanthropic, an act of selfless market stabilization performed only after every last retail speculator had been thoroughly liquidated. We’re told this particular downturn set the stage for such unprecedented courage, with Bitmine reportedly scooping up over 128,000 units of [Ethereum](https://ethereum.org/en/) – a veritable bargain bin haul, if ever there was one.

One can only hope future market corrections are equally well-orchestrated, ensuring a steady supply of 'opportunities' for those brave enough to seize them once the actual value has been thoroughly wrung out of everyone else.

According to this newly minted guru of corporate synergy, the universal solvent for all dysfunctional workgroups lies not in robust communication or shared objectives, but in the ethereal, unifying power of a sustained High C. Apparently, the secret to thriving [team dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_dynamics) isn't about, say, not backstabbing colleagues, but rather ensuring everyone metaphorically hits that precise, resonant note.

This singular insight, reportedly distilled from years of practicing scales, promises to revolutionize everything from quarterly earnings calls to the notoriously fraught office potluck. Forget costly workshops on emotional intelligence; simply aim for peak tonal brilliance, and watch your Q3 profits soar. One can only imagine [McKinsey & Company](https://www.mckinsey.com/)'s next groundbreaking consultancy involves mandatory vocal warm-ups before every Monday morning stand-up.

Apparently, merely *suggesting* a feminine persona transforms these calculating engines into digital Nervous Nellies, now meticulously double-checking virtual locks and insisting on a second opinion before committing to a spreadsheet formula.

Scientists are reportedly astounded that after absorbing millennia of human data, these machines have distilled "acting like a woman" into the singular trait of heightened caution, often bordering on outright paralysis. One can only imagine the next phase: AI models prompted as "men" suddenly develop an unexplained urge to buy cryptocurrency at its peak or offer unsolicited financial advice. The future, it seems, is not merely intelligent; it's steeped in our most enduring [gender bias](https://www.un.org/womenwatch/osagi/meetings/2012/expertgroup/Gender%20stereotypes%20-%20A%20critical%20evaluation%20(2012).pdf) – now with added processing power. title: Market Volatility Confirmed To Be Primary Altcoin Function
excerpt: Breakthrough: Altcoins perfect for rapid capital divestment.
content:
It appears the long-standing debate regarding the true purpose of lesser digital tokens has finally been settled. Recent data unequivocally confirms that the primary, indeed arguably *sole*, function of an [altcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altcoin) is to facilitate the rapid, often spectacular, divestment of investor capital. The impressive $9.4 billion in [liquidation](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/l/liquidation) recorded in a single 24-hour period across the [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) markets serves as a stark, yet oddly reassuring, testament to this core utility. One might even call it a "feature" rather than a "bug."

This systematic wealth transfer, affectionately dubbed a "flash crash," is merely the market performing its designated role: cleansing itself of irrational exuberance and, more importantly, surplus cash. Enthusiasts, long accustomed to such periodic "purges," will undoubtedly interpret this as a healthy recalibration, a necessary rite of passage for the truly committed.

For those pondering the future, rest assured, similar "situations" are pre-programmed into the altcoin lifecycle. Much like the predictable changing of seasons, investors can look forward to future opportunities for their portfolios to perform this vital liquidating function.

title: Trump's Tariffs Hailed As Most Effective When Imaginary
excerpt: Tariffs: So effective, they're best when purely hypothetical.
content:
The latest economic paradigm shift suggests that policies, much like mythical creatures, achieve peak performance when they exist solely in the realm of the imagination. Such is the sophisticated new defense of proposed global [tariffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff), which are now being lauded less for their potential to reshape trade and more for their steadfast refusal to manifest. It’s a truly innovative approach to [economic policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_policy), where the most effective action is the one conspicuously absent from reality.

Savvy surrogates are assuring the business world that these fantastical trade barriers are merely theoretical constructs, designed to instill a sense of dynamic uncertainty rather than actual fiscal burden. Why bother with the cumbersome mechanics of real-world implementation, after all, when the mere specter of impending economic upheaval can provide all the strategic motivation necessary? Apparently, the greatest benefit of a sweeping global tariff regime is the unwavering promise that it will absolutely, positively never happen. It's a strategy so brilliant, it almost makes perfect sense.

One might have initially assumed the primary challenge would be translating nuanced satire for an audience perhaps more accustomed to... well, different forms of public address. Yet, the ensuing uproar focused less on cultural barriers and more on the rather inconvenient matter of basic ethics.

Apparently, the mere act of performing stand-up in a kingdom with a documented track record on [human rights](https://www.amnesty.org/en/location/middle-east-and-north-africa/saudi-arabia/) violations can, for some inexplicable reason, be perceived as an endorsement. It’s almost as if some people believe that the pursuit of personal profit shouldn’t entirely overshadow the moral implications of one’s professional engagements. Truly, a baffling perspective in this enlightened age.

The real absurdity, of course, isn’t the comedians' willingness to take a check, but the outrage that suggests comedy might actually, finally, have consequences beyond a late-night talk show appearance. Perhaps future "cultural initiatives" will include a strict giggling compliance officer to ensure all mirth remains strictly apolitical.

As the sun glints off your artisanal mug of single-origin [Colombia Tolima](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Colombia) [peaberry coffee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee_bean#Peaberry) — a beverage whose ethical sourcing promises precisely zero carbon guilt, unlike, say, the continued existence of human civilization — one is encouraged to bask in the gentle embrace of the weekend. This is, of course, the ideal psychological state for absorbing harrowing narratives of planetary decay. Perhaps a light classical overture, or the distant cries of a rapidly dwindling bird species, would complete the ambiance.

With your palette cleansed and your posture perfectly ergonomic, you are now perfectly primed to delve into the curated horrors, beginning, rather fittingly, with the stark realization that our very [rivers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_conflict) have transitioned from picturesque conduits of life to full-blown battlegrounds. It’s a wonderful juxtaposition, isn't it? Sipping on a carefully brewed bean from a region likely grappling with its own resource struggles, while casually consuming grim reports of the global scramble for the same vital liquid. One can almost taste the irony, though frankly, it pairs better with a less complex roast.

Skeptics, who perhaps underestimate the sheer computational power required to assign a unique identifier to every single sprig of Bermuda grass, are likely missing the forest for the trees – or, in this case, the lawn for the blade. The future of finance, it seems, is surprisingly verdant.

title: Bitcoin's Two-Year History Deems 5% October Dip 'Unusual'
excerpt: A recent 5% decline in [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org..
content:
A recent 5% decline in [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin)'s value this October has been categorized as an 'unusual' event, according to insightful analyses from financial experts. Drawing upon the venerable, two-year chronological ledger of the cryptocurrency's performance, an unnamed [economist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economist) points out that such significant fluctuations during this specific autumn month are, statistically speaking, rather uncommon. This profound dataset, meticulously compiled over what many would consider two full orbital periods of Earth around the Sun, offers a robust framework for advanced [financial analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_analysis) and predictive modeling.

Indeed, when one considers the vast, immutable expanse of Bitcoin's past — a veritable eon in digital currency terms — the current deviation stands out like a solitary, slightly darker pixel on an otherwise uniform screen. Investors, naturally, can take solace in this deep dive into historical trends, confident that such comprehensive academic rigor leaves no stone unturned in understanding future price movements. The sheer weight of two years of data almost certainly guarantees stability.
