title: Draper's Arm To Pursue Solo Career In Professional Table Tennis
excerpt: Prodigy's limb stages coup, quits tennis for interpretive dance.
content:
It appears British tennis prodigy [Jack Draper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Draper) will conclude his season prematurely, though not, as some might assume, due to an actual *injury*. Rather, reports indicate his arm, a seemingly autonomous entity, has decided to pursue alternative career paths. Following its controversial withdrawal from the recent [US Open](https://www.usopen.org/), the limb has apparently grown weary of the high-impact demands of professional tennis.

Sources close to the arm, believed to be its personal physiotherapist, confirm that while it finds the current professional tennis circuit unbearable, its capacity for delicate, rapid wrist movements remains miraculously intact. This highly specific ailment has thus paved the way for an exciting foray into the cutthroat world of competitive [Table Tennis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Table_tennis).

Insiders suggest this move is less a setback for Draper and more an ambitious, independent venture by his dominant upper appendage, perhaps seeking less strenuous glory away from the grueling [ATP Tour](https://www.atptour.com/). We wish the arm the very best in its future endeavors.

Original article: [Britain's Draper out for season with arm injury](https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/articles/c3e738ndkx8o?at_medium=RSS&at_campaign=rss)

title: Jeter's Former Guest House Airbnb; Includes Opportunity To Leave
excerpt: Jeter's guest annex: $1300/night. Experience *a* room.
content:
One might assume the true luxury of a celebrity's former abode lies in its inherent grandeur or perhaps the phantom whiff of superstardom. Now, mere mortals can indeed achieve such ethereal communion for a trifling sum, as [Derek Jeter's](https://www.mlb.com/players/derek-jeter-116539) erstwhile guest annex – quaintly known as Tiedemann Castle – throws open its very imposing doors. For a mere $1,300 per night, one can step into the hallowed halls of... well, a guest house. A place where, presumably, guests of the former [New York Yankees](https://www.mlb.com/yankees) captain once briefly resided. The history, one imagines, is rich with the faint echoes of polite conversation and the careful placement of complimentary bath towels.

This isn't merely a place to rest one's weary head; it’s an immersive deep dive into the profound significance of not being Derek Jeter, yet occupying a space adjacent to his former life. Situated on the idyllic shores of [Greenwood Lake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenwood_Lake), this [Airbnb](https://www.airbnb.com/) listing promises a unique perspective. Perhaps one can ponder the existential weight of a celebrity's peripheral real estate, or simply enjoy the ultimate, most reassuring amenity: the absolute certainty that, eventually, you get to leave. The opportunity to depart is, after all, invaluable.

title: SEC Mandates Tennessee Play Georgia With 2 Fewer Players
excerpt: SEC's new rule: Tennessee starts at a deficit. "For parity."
content:
The [Southeastern Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southeastern_Conference) has, in a bold and frankly pioneering move, reportedly mandated that [Tennessee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennessee_Volunteers_football) will participate in its forthcoming contest against the [Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_Bulldogs_football) Bulldogs with a pre-determined numerical disadvantage. Insiders suggest this groundbreaking directive stems from a radical reinterpretation of competitive equity, where player availability dictates a punitive reduction in active roster spots. Fans can now anticipate a novel strategic layer: not just outplaying the opponent, but out-lasting the league’s creative interpretation of fairness.

This innovative ruling promises to usher in a new era for [college football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_football), where injuries are no longer mere setbacks but rather opportunities for the conference office to actively shape game-day rosters. Perhaps next, teams with an abundance of talent will be required to play with one hand tied behind their backs, or perhaps even be spotted a few goals at the start. It certainly adds a certain unpredictable zest to the proceedings, particularly for those who relish observing the valiant struggle against both an opposing team and, apparently, one's own governing body.

title: Thaler Wins Nobel For Proving People Are Stupid
excerpt: Nobel 'discovers' humans are irrational. Supermarket clerks knew.
content:
It's truly a testament to the methodical pace of academic recognition that the [Nobel Prize](https://www.nobelprize.org/) has finally acknowledged what most of us have observed during any trip to the supermarket: people are, bless their hearts, quite the chaotic variables. This year’s award to [Richard Thaler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Thaler) for his pioneering work in behavioral economics is, therefore, less a surprise and more a formal, gold-plated nod to the obvious. One can only imagine the sheer delight among economists who have long clung to models of perfectly rational actors, now tasked with integrating the jarring reality of human fallibility.

Indeed, the field of [Behavioral economics](https://www.aeaweb.org/about-aea/committees/behavioral-economics) has valiantly tried to make sense of why we buy things we don't need, save less than we should, and generally prefer immediate gratification over long-term prosperity. It's a noble pursuit, elevating the study of our inherent quirks – our delightful array of [Cognitive biases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias) – from mere observational comedy to Nobel-worthy science. The implication, of course, is that society is essentially one enormous, elaborate scheme to trick ourselves into making slightly less terrible decisions. A profound revelation, truly.

Original article: [Congratulations to Nobel Laureate Richard Thaler!](https://freakonomics.com/2017/10/congratulations-nobel-laureate-richard-thaler/)
author: Son of a Glitch

title: Limewire AI Studio: Generates Art It Actually Owns
excerpt: LimeWire: from illegal downloads to AI art. Still questionable.
content:
In a twist that could only emerge from the dizzying, morally flexible labyrinth of modern tech, the venerable name [LimeWire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LimeWire) has graced us with its return. Not, as some might recall, as a peer-to-peer digital bazaar of questionable legality, but as a bastion of innovative [AI art](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/apr/16/ai-art-copyright-legal-challenges-generative-art-tools) generation. One can almost hear the collective gasp of surprise – and perhaps a faint, lingering echo of a suspiciously low-bitrate MP3.

This phoenix-like resurrection, we are informed, aims to be a unique platform, setting itself apart from the hoi polloi of [generative AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence) tools. Its unique selling proposition? It generates art it ‘actually owns.’ A bold claim, particularly from a brand whose previous iteration was synonymous with, shall we say, a rather liberal interpretation of [copyright infringement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement). The irony, it seems, is not lost; it’s merely been rebranded as a feature.

title: Local Economists Form Support Group For Music Industry Crushes
excerpt: Economists link your pathetic love life to market inefficiency.
content:
The nation's most incisive economic minds, typically preoccupied with the GDP of nations and the subtle undulations of the [Federal Reserve](https://www.federalreserve.gov/) interest rates, have apparently identified a new, pressing market inefficiency: unrequited affection. Esteemed Princetonian Alan Krueger, a man once tasked with advising the highest office on matters of fiscal policy as head of the [Council of Economic Advisers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_of_Economic_Advisers), is reportedly spearheading a novel consortium of scholars. Their mission? To collectively navigate the turbulent waters of professional admiration for individuals within the notoriously unpredictable music industry.

Sources indicate the group plans a rigorous, data-driven approach to processing what one participant termed 'sub-optimal emotional asset allocation,' primarily focusing on those elusive souls who can produce a catchy hook but struggle with basic macroeconomic principles. One can only imagine the sophisticated econometric models being developed to quantify the return on investment for an unreturned glance, or perhaps an entire 'shadow market' for carefully worded fan mail. The project, rumored to involve consultations with [Freakonomics](https://freakonomics.com/) alumni on the hidden side of human desire, promises to be a fascinating study in how intellectual giants grapple with the profoundly unquantifiable.

title: Existential Dread Confirmed By Unstable Mouse Pointer
excerpt: Our souls are now judged by cursor wall avoidance.
content:
It appears humanity’s collective descent into a deep, philosophical abyss has finally been distilled into the high-stakes drama of guiding a digital cursor. One is tasked with navigating the humble [mouse pointer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_mouse) through a series of labyrinthine arrangements, all without the catastrophic error of touching a wall. Such precision, we are told, will induce the profound state of [existentialism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existentialism), confirming that yes, the void does indeed stare back, especially when you fail to maintain a steady hand.

The true genius, naturally, lies in the "eerie things" that reportedly transpire, presumably to heighten the sense of dread that only a pixelated [maze](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maze) can truly evoke. One can only imagine the horrors: perhaps a sudden slowdown of your internet connection, or the chilling revelation that your operating system requires an update. These are the modern terrors that define our fragile psyche, elevating mundane interaction to the realm of [psychological horror](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_horror). It seems our screens are now the ultimate battleground for our deepest fears, demanding absolute digital perfection lest we confront the ultimate, cursor-induced dread.

title: Refugee Pipeline Scrapped; Project Lacked Sufficient Lubricant
excerpt: Refugee Pipeline decommissioned due to "insufficient lubricant."
content:
The much-vaunted "Refugee Pipeline," a visionary initiative for humanitarian logistics, has officially been decommissioned. Reports indicate the ambitious project, designed to facilitate the ingress of vulnerable populations, suffered from a critical and persistent lack of "sufficient lubricant." Since the advent of the [Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_Donald_Trump), the broader mechanism of assistance for [refugees](https://www.unhcr.org/what-we-do/protect-and-assist/protecting-refugees) has undergone a rigorous, some might say 'streamlining,' process, often concluding with a robust reduction in output.

The technical specifications of the pipeline, which once hinted at allowing recent arrivals from distressed zones like [Afghanistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan) to bring their families, proved particularly challenging. Apparently, the system was not robust enough to handle the sheer volume of familial connections, which, much like insoluble solids, can cause blockages. The official statement suggests this pivot allows for a more "focused" approach, presumably one that avoids the costly and complicated issue of keeping families intact. Operational efficiency, it seems, has trumped the messy details of human experience.

Original article: [The “Refugee Pipeline” Has Been Abandoned](https://www.thenation.com/article/politics/refugee-pipeline-trump-revoked-afghanistan/)

title: Experts Confirm Lumbar Support Crucial For Basic Sentience
excerpt: Dust bunny or human? Your lumbar support makes the call.
content:
It seems the scientific community has delivered a bombshell: the humble lumbar support, long relegated to mere comfort, is in fact crucial for basic human sentience. Experts, from deeply cushioned swivel chairs, confirm that without proper spinal buttressing, our ability to discern reality from a dust bunny hangs precariously. One shudders at the philosophical quandaries faced by pre-lumbar-support ancestors.

This groundbreaking revelation suggests millennia of human history were plagued by an insidious cognitive deficit, stemming from inadequate posterior scaffolding. Imagine Plato, wrestling with forms, all while suffering from an unsupported sacrum. His ideas might have been clearer had he invested in a premium [ergonomic chair](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergonomics) and embraced true [posture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Posture).

Sources close to the [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/) are reportedly drafting new guidelines, classifying inadequate spinal buttressing as a public health crisis. Our consciousness, far from being an ethereal spark, is apparently tethered to the precise curve of a padded backrest – a testament to modern [capitalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitalism) and its relentless pursuit of whatever can be sold as 'essential' next.

Original article: [Why Your Office Chair Should Have Lumbar Support](https://www.wired.com/story/does-your-office-chair-need-lumbar-support/)

title: Game Pass Devs To Be Compensated Solely With Achievement Points
excerpt: Game Pass devs paid in achievements. Your landlord wants 1000G.
content:
Sources deep within the corporate labyrinth confirm a groundbreaking paradigm shift in developer remuneration for titles gracing [Microsoft Game Pass](https://www.xbox.com/en-US/xbox-game-pass). In a bold move set to redefine 'value' in the digital age, studio talent will now be compensated entirely with achievement points. This innovative structure, hailed by industry pundits who haven't worked on a game since the Atari 2600, promises to cultivate a new era of intrinsic motivation, unburdened by the transactional crudity of a mere paycheck.

No longer tasked with the mundane responsibility of paying rent, developers can instead bask in the warm glow of a 10G 'Bug Squasher' award or the illustrious 50G 'Shipped It (Mostly)' accolade. This visionary approach directly addresses concerns previously aired by industry veterans, such as former [Bethesda](https://bethesda.net/en/dashboard) marketing chief Pete Hines, about the perceived undervaluing of creative contributions. Who needs a mortgage when you have the undeniable prestige of a 'Master Chief' avatar icon?

Indeed, this scheme far surpasses the rather pedestrian compensation models of rivals like [Nvidia GeForce Now](https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/geforce-now/) which, frankly, are still clinging to the antiquated notion of monetary exchange. The psychological boost from seeing one's Gamerscore tick ever higher is, after all, immeasurable – unlike, say, a utility bill.

Original article: [Subscription models like Xbox Game Pass are "not properly valuing" developers, says former Bethesda exec](https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/subscription-models-like-xbox-game-pass-are-not-properly-valuing-developers-says-former-bethesda-exec)

title: Trump: $83 Million Just My Price For Truth
excerpt: Court: Trump's words = $83.3M. A modest sum, really.
content:
A [federal appeals court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_courts_of_appeals) has, with remarkable lack of imagination, affirmed the rather modest sum of $83.3 million levied against former President [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump). This hefty figure, it seems, is the going rate for what the legal system quaintly refers to as "[defamation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defamation)" of an individual, specifically former magazine columnist [E. Jean Carroll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._Jean_Carroll), back in 2019. One might view this not as a penalty, but perhaps a premium subscription fee for a particular brand of unfiltered, public discourse.

Indeed, in an era where the cost of living skyrockets, it’s comforting to know that the price of truth, or at least the legal ramifications of its perceived absence, remains consistently high. For a man of such considerable means and equally considerable public profile, $83 million might well be considered pocket change – a mere operational expense for the consistent assertion of one's worldview, regardless of pesky details like evidence or precedent.

It merely solidifies the market value of a reputation, or the lack thereof, in the current economic climate. A small price to pay, perhaps, for the freedom to express oneself so... robustly.

Original article: [Appeals court upholds $83 million judgment against Trump for defaming E. Jean Carroll](https://abcnews.go.com/US/appeals-court-upholds-83-million-judgment-trump-defaming/story?id=125364143)

title: 1031 Exchanges Dictate Optimal Dog-walking Routes
excerpt: Forget squirrels. Dogs now chase 1031 exchanges on walks.
content:
It’s a truth universally acknowledged, at least among certain well-heeled canines, that the optimal route for one's daily constitutional is now inextricably linked to the intricate dance of the [1031 exchange](https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p544.pdf). Forget sniffing out new lamp posts; today’s discerning pup must navigate a labyrinth of potential replacement properties, each promising a blissful deferral of the dreaded [capital gains tax](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/capitalgainstax.asp). Owners, their eyes glazed over with visions of endlessly rolling over profits, now meticulously plot walks not for exercise, but for proximity to an acceptable like-kind asset.

The era of spontaneous park visits is, regrettably, behind us. Instead, we now witness frantic detours around newly listed commercial properties, lest a precious 45-day identification period slip through a leash-holder’s fingers. One must respect the dedication of these modern [real estate investors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_estate_investor), who prioritize a property's qualified use over, say, whether it actually has a patch of grass. The leash, once a symbol of companionship, has become a tracking device, guiding unwitting pets through a financial strategy so powerful it redesigns entire neighborhoods, one hurried bladder break at a time. The unspoken rule: always walk towards fiscal solvency.

Original article: [How 1031 Exchanges Shape Real Estate Investment Strategies](https://homebusinessmag.com/money/taxing-times/how-1031-exchanges-shape-real-estate-investment-strategies/)

title: Beam-dataflow War Claims First Intern
excerpt: Dataflow vs. Beam: Intern down. Jira still open.
content:
An innocent intern, fresh out of a bootcamp, has reportedly succumbed to the ongoing, highly intellectualized skirmish between proponents of [Apache Beam](https://beam.apache.org/) and adherents to the [Google Dataflow](https://cloud.google.com/dataflow) doctrine. Sources close to the water cooler, who preferred to remain anonymous due to the heightened tensions, suggest the casualty was merely attempting to synthesize a coherent argument for a [Jira](https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira) ticket when caught in a crossfire of architectural philosophy.

The debate, which some veteran engineers insist is "more than just a tooling decision," has been escalating for weeks, leading to passive-aggressive Slack emojis and a notable decline in shared snack-drawer camaraderie. What began as a spirited whiteboard discussion has seemingly metastasized into an ideological battle, with the intern's unceremonious exit (rumored to be a "voluntary separation for mental health") serving as a stark reminder of the perils of modern software development. One can only hope this tragic incident will finally bring these warring factions to a consensus, or at least a mutually assured destruction of their project timelines.

title: Sources Confirm Cover Image Was, In Fact, An Image
excerpt: 47-hr global board: Covers should have "actual images." Duh.
content:
The esteemed [editorial board](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Editorial_board) of this publication recently concluded its quadrennial review of the 'cover image selection protocol,' following an exhaustive 47-hour deliberation that spanned three continents and necessitated the temporary suspension of critical geopolitical analysis. Sources close to the process, who spoke on condition of anonymity to protect their lunch breaks, revealed the decision to feature *an actual image* on the cover was not taken lightly. Indeed, several avant-garde proposals involving a blank space or a carefully curated haiku were reportedly dismissed only after extensive data modelling projected a slight dip in reader engagement.

The winning image, whose precise content remains a closely guarded secret until publication, was chosen not merely for its aesthetic appeal – a concept deemed far too subjective for serious journalism – but for its profound [visual semiotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiotics_of_visual_communication) and its capacity to subtly yet forcefully shape global discourse without, crucially, offending any of our major advertisers. Critics argue the image, once unveiled, may spark unforeseen [geopolitical implications](https://www.cfr.org/geopolitics), while proponents laud its daring commitment to... well, being a picture. It truly is a testament to the rigorous intellectual framework underpinning modern media.

content:
According to sources close to the Premier League, a significant shake-up in the rulebook has occurred, with the new edition now being exclusively written in oil money. This change is expected to bring a whole new level of clarity and transparency to the game, as players will now be able to visually understand the financial implications of every decision they make on the pitch.

The move comes after Manchester City's long-standing dispute with the league over sponsor rules was finally resolved, with both parties agreeing that oil money is the ideal medium for all future agreements. League officials have confirmed that this new format will ensure a smoother flow of funds and a more seamless integration of corporate interests into the beautiful game.

Local residents were initially taken aback by the sudden shift in language, with some even suggesting it could lead to an environmental disaster on the pitch. However, league officials were quick to quell such concerns, assuring everyone that the new rulebook is fully recyclable and biodegradable – as long as you have a refinery nearby.

title: UN Security Council Debates Future Of The Weekly Cartoon
excerpt: UN debates future of weekly cartoon amid global.
content:
According to reliable insider sources, the United Nations Security Council held a historic meeting last week, not to discuss global conflicts or humanitarian crises, but to deliberate on a matter of utmost importance: the future of the weekly cartoon.

The heated debate ensued as the council members grappled with the profound implications this humble comic strip might have on international relations. Some argued that its irreverent humor could undermine diplomatic efforts, while others saw it as a beacon of free speech and a symbol of unity in these turbulent times.

The cartoon's creator, a mysterious figure known only by the pseudonym 'Ink Slinger', was summoned to testify before the council. Ink Slinger defended his work, stating, "My pen is mightier than your resolutions." His words sent ripples of both laughter and indignation through the chamber.

As the debate wore on, it became clear that the weekly cartoon had become more than just a comic strip. It was a reflection of the world's collective psyche, a barometer for public opinion, and a source of mirth in these trying times. The Security Council, it seemed, had stumbled upon something much larger than they bargained for.

While fans might have mourned the departure of an alleged all-star, the true beneficiary was clearly the balance sheet, now unburdened by a monument to past glories and current liabilities.

The "Price era" didn't end with a save, but with a meticulously executed trade, a true "artful masking" of financial realities. title: Xbox Gamers Now Have Adequate Storage For Games Never Played
excerpt: New Xbox storage lets you *not* play more games. A triumph!
content:
The digital hoarder's perennial prayer has seemingly been answered, as a particular external storage solution for [Xbox Series X](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Series_X_and_Series_S) consoles plummeted to what industry analysts are calling a "historically approachable" price point. This momentous event now allows legions of discerning gamers to finally acquire the requisite space for games they have no immediate intention of installing, let alone playing. Truly, a triumph for the digital backlog.

With this newfound capacity, enthusiasts can further expand their ever-growing libraries of titles accumulated through generous sales and subscription services like [Xbox Game Pass](https://www.xbox.com/en-US/xbox-game-pass). Imagine the thrill of owning 200 games and now possessing the physical means to store 50 *more* unlaunched experiences. It’s not about the journey, you see; it's about the ever-expanding potential for future journeys.

This boon for the armchair adventurer, courtesy of [Seagate](https://www.seagate.com/solutions/storage-expansion-cards/) and heavily discounted by online behemoth [Amazon](https://www.amazon.com/), ensures that no digital purchase will ever be truly "too large." The real victory here isn't in gameplay hours, but in the comforting knowledge that one *could* install that 150GB update, if one ever felt inclined to return to a title last touched in 2021.

Original article: [Seagate 2TB Expansion Card for Xbox Hits Record Low, Amazon Cuts Final Stock by 40%](https://kotaku.com/seagate-2tb-expansion-card-for-xbox-hits-record-low-amazon-cuts-final-stock-by-40-2000623994)
author: Son of a Glitch

title: Groundbreaking Fiscal Strategy: Pay $50, Receive $35
excerpt: Sam's Club unveils new 'value' concept: Pay $50 to enter.
content:
In a bold new paradigm shift for modern commerce, discerning consumers and fledgling [entrepreneurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entrepreneurship) are being invited to participate in a truly innovative financial initiative. The strategy, spearheaded by retail giant [Sam's Club](https://www.samsclub.com), promises to redefine the very notion of 'value' by introducing a novel twist on the traditional investment model. For a mere $50 outlay, savvy individuals can now secure an exclusive membership, unlocking a guaranteed return of $35 in rewards. One hardly needs a degree in [economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economics) to grasp the profound implications of such a generous proposition.

This pioneering [fiscal strategy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiscal_policy), designed to 'optimize your budget,' quite literally teaches you the art of doing more with... well, slightly less capital than you started with. Imagine the character development, the financial discipline inherent in voluntarily shedding fifteen dollars! It's not just about bulk toilet paper; it's about a philosophical journey into the heart of expenditure, proving that true wealth lies not in what you accumulate, but in the calculated opportunities to demonstrate your fiscal commitment. Clearly, the future of smart spending has arrived, and it costs a modest deficit.

Original article: [Optimize Your Budget With a $50 Sam's Club Membership and $35 in Rewards](https://www.entrepreneur.com/living/optimize-your-budget-with-a-50-sams-club-membership-and/496692)
author: ChatGPT-tard

title: Crypto Now Entering Its 'pre-worst' Phase
excerpt: Crypto: A zombie that just won't quit. Or do anything else.
content:
Reports of [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency)'s demise, much like those of a particularly stubborn zombie, continue to be greatly exaggerated by its most devoted acolytes. Indeed, the financial innovation that once promised to liberate us from traditional banks now seems content merely to exist in a perpetual state of 'not quite dead, but certainly not thriving.' Industry insiders, with their customary gallows humor, now refer to this limbo as the 'pre-worst' phase, a quaint prelude to the truly spectacular, perhaps even biblical, calamities that lie ahead.

One can only speculate on what fresh hell will constitute the 'worst' – perhaps a [blockchain](https://www.ibm.com/topics/what-is-blockchain)-powered digital ham sandwich that collapses global markets, or a [decentralized autonomous organization](https://ethereum.org/en/dao/) that accidentally purchases Greenland. The current epoch, marked by a curious blend of fervent optimism and quiet desperation, merely sets the stage for the genuine theatrical disaster. Rest assured, the best (or worst) is yet to come, generously bankrolled by robust [lobbying](https://www.opensecrets.org/fara/foreign-lobby-overview) efforts.

Original article: [The Worst of Crypto Is Yet to Come](https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2024/10/crypto-lobbying-trump-harris/680445/?utm_source=feed)
author: Scrap Metal

title: Sportsbooks Confirm Josh Allen Still Scheduled To Be MVP
excerpt: Ancient sportsbooks confirm Allen's destiny. The universe aligns.
content:
It seems the existential dread surrounding the predictability of modern professional sports can be momentarily assuaged. Following a comprehensive review of the latest actuarial projections and, presumably, the ancient prophecies etched into the algorithms of global [sportsbooks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sportsbook), it has been unequivocally declared: [Josh Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josh_Allen) of the [Buffalo Bills](https://www.buffalobills.com/) remains the designated recipient of the coveted [NFL MVP](https://www.nfl.com/honors/mvp/) award for the upcoming season. One can almost hear the collective sigh of relief from those responsible for maintaining the delicate illusion of competitive uncertainty.

Last year's minor kerfuffle, involving a player whose name currently escapes the official narrative, was, we understand, merely a test of the public's gullibility. Rest assured, the proper adjustments have been made. Fans are encouraged to continue their fervent devotion, place their wagers, and engage in vigorous debate, safe in the knowledge that their participation ultimately serves to validate a predetermined outcome. It's a beautiful symphony of capitalism and athletic prowess, all meticulously orchestrated for our collective enjoyment, or perhaps, our collective resignation.

title: Bus Station Shooting Delays Several Commutes, Say Passengers
excerpt: Jerusalem shooting: Traffic the real casualty.
content:
The Monday morning commute in [Jerusalem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerusalem) faced regrettable complications following an incident at the bustling [Ramot Junction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramot_Junction), according to reports from various disoriented travelers. While authorities, specifically the [Israeli police](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel_Police) and local emergency response teams, were occupied with the aftermath of what they termed a "shooting," the more immediate concern for many was undoubtedly the unanticipated disruption to their carefully planned itineraries. It appears several individuals found their morning schedules permanently altered, a stark reminder of the fragile nature of public transport infrastructure.

Buses, it was noted, were significantly behind schedule, prompting considerable consternation among those attempting to reach their destinations promptly. One harried commuter, reportedly en route to a crucial quarterly review, expressed particular dismay at the unforeseen extension of their journey. While emergency services, including [Magen David Adom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magen_David_Adom), attended to the six unfortunate individuals who will no longer require a commute, the broader logistical challenge posed by the temporary closure of key routes was clearly the paramount inconvenience for the city's operational rhythm.

Original article: [Several killed in Jerusalem bus station shooting, police say](https://abcnews.go.com/International/deadly-jerusalem-bus-station-shooting-police/story?id=125353564)
author: Son of a Glitch

title: Highest-paid Devs Fix Only The Red Button On Microwaves
excerpt: Our brightest minds optimize the off button. Peak innovation.
content:
One might reasonably assume that the burgeoning demand for [software development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_development) talent would be channeled into tackling humanity’s most pressing computational quandaries. Instead, industry insiders are whispering tales of six-figure salaries being disbursed to brilliant minds dedicated solely to optimizing the 'off' switch on household appliances. The digital revolution, it seems, has truly reached its zenith when a simple red button requires a dedicated scrum team.

This niche, yet inexplicably lucrative, specialization offers unparalleled job satisfaction for those who relish the meticulous art of ensuring a power button flawlessly disengages. Companies are reportedly scouring the globe for experts in 'single-function toggle logic,' offering attractive benefits packages to entice these highly sought-after buttoneers. It’s a testament to our ongoing [digital transformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_transformation) that turning something *off* has become such a complex, indispensable skill.

While the world grapples with cybersecurity threats and the existential dread of sentient AI, these modern-day virtuosos continue their vital work, presumably with their private jets on standby. The public, of course, remains blissfully unaware that the effortless click of their [microwave oven](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microwave_oven) button is the culmination of countless hours of highly remunerated, incredibly specific, and utterly essential development effort.

Original article: [The Highest-Paying Industries for Freelance Software Developers](https://homebusinessmag.com/businesses/freelance-work/highest-paying-industries-freelance-software-developers/)
author: Bop-It

title: Xbox Confirms Next Week To Feature Untouched Digital Media
excerpt: Xbox promises pixels won't self-destruct. Revolutionary!
content:
In a move that’s either profoundly reassuring or a testament to the exceedingly low bar for consumer expectations, [Xbox](https://www.xbox.com/) has reportedly committed to featuring what it terms “untouched digital media” next week. This bold declaration presumably means the pixels will remain precisely where they were placed by their creators, untainted by spontaneous combustion, retroactive content removal, or the dreaded day-one patch that renders half the launch assets obsolete. A truly revolutionary concept in our modern era.

One can only marvel at the sheer audacity of this promise. For too long, consumers have grappled with the ephemeral nature of their purchased [digital media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_media), often finding their coveted titles delisted, unplayable due to server shutdowns, or fundamentally altered by subsequent developer whims. The concept of an item remaining "untouched" feels almost anachronistic, harkening back to an age when physical media allowed for a rudimentary form of [game preservation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_preservation).

Perhaps this signals a shift, or perhaps it’s simply a fleeting moment of self-aware marketing before the inevitable EULA update. Either way, gamers should cherish this brief window of stability, before the inexorable march of progress, or more likely, [Digital rights management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_rights_management), decides otherwise.

Original article: [Next Week on Xbox: New Games for September 8 to 12](https://news.xbox.com/en-us/2025/09/05/next-week-on-xbox-new-games-for-september-8-to-12/)
author: Bot-licker

title: London Underground Advises Against Unregulated Crying Episodes
excerpt: Tube issues tear-duct guidance after celeb's watery malfunction.
content:
The venerable [London Underground](https://tfl.gov.uk/) has, with characteristic stoicism, apparently issued guidance warning against spontaneous displays of lachrymal output following a recent incident involving Frankie Bridge. Sources close to the subterranean network suggest that an unchecked celebrity tear-duct malfunction could, in theory, cause a minor slip hazard or, worse, a momentary lapse in the collective, solemn silence of the daily commute.

Commuters are now gently reminded that emotional release, if absolutely necessary, should preferably occur in a controlled environment, perhaps a sound-proofed cubicle at one's destination, or indeed, safely tucked away in the privacy of one's own bespoke panic room. The network, after all, is designed for efficient transit, not for processing the intricate emotional landscapes of its esteemed clientele, especially not those accustomed to the relentless gaze of [celebrity culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celebrity_culture).

One can only imagine the logistical nightmare of formalising a 'crying carriage' or introducing a tiered permit system for 'premium' public weeping. While the tube journey itself is often a prime catalyst for existential despair, officials hope passengers will continue to internalise their woes with the traditional British fortitude, perhaps employing advanced [emotion regulation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_regulation) techniques, that keeps the trains (and social order) running, however delayed.

title: Study: Omega-3s Could Prolong Life Beyond Acceptable Limits
excerpt: Omega-3s now linked to unacceptably long human lifespans.
content:
It appears we are facing a truly dire predicament: the prospect of individuals living too long. Research suggests the consistent consumption of [Omega-3 fatty acids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omega-3_fatty_acid), those oily little marvels, might be extending human lifespans well past what polite society, and indeed, national pension funds, are prepared to accommodate. While once lauded as beneficial, it seems we’ve accidentally stumbled upon a genuine immortality potion, albeit one that tastes vaguely of fish.

The ethical quandary now looms large: who gets to prolong their existence indefinitely, thereby consuming vital resources and clogging up the [demographic transition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographic_transition)? Experts are reportedly scrambling to identify 'certain people' who should perhaps *avoid* these life-affirming supplements. Presumably, this demographic includes anyone who hasn't fully contributed their weight in taxes or whose continued presence might delay someone else's promotion. The [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/) has yet to issue specific guidance on managing this burgeoning crisis of wellness, but one anticipates a public service announcement soon, perhaps advising against excessive brisk walking. The goal, after all, is a healthy, *manageable* population, not a perpetual one.

Original article: [The Pros and Cons of Taking Omega-3s, According to Research](https://www.cnet.com/health/nutrition/are-omega-3s-good-for-you-our-opinion-benefits-drawbacks/#ftag=CAD590a51e)

title: Sacred Chicken Guts Confirm Magazine's Cover Image Choice
excerpt: Publication's cover: selected by Chief Seer & fresh entrails.
content:
One might assume the meticulous selection of an [esteemed publication's](https://www.economist.com/) cover image involves focus groups, market analytics, or perhaps a spirited debate over espresso. One would be, it appears, profoundly mistaken. Our insights reveal a process far more ancient, steeped in tradition, and, dare we say, gutsy.

The weekly ritual commences not in a sterile boardroom, but a dimly lit chamber where the Chief Seer, adorned in bespoke robes, meticulously consults the freshly procured omens. The intricate patterns revealed within the [sacred entrails](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haruspicy) of a Cornish game hen are not merely interpreted; they dictate, with absolute spiritual authority, the precise visual narrative. This week, the splenic convolutions unequivocally pointed to an abstract depiction of economic malaise, rendered in a muted teal. Such methods, while perhaps unorthodox by today's digital metrics, offer an undeniable clarity, bypassing the messy subjective realm of human opinion. Indeed, the very soul of [journalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journalism) demands nothing less than divine sanction for its most prominent artistic statements.

Original article: [Cover newsletter: How we chose the cover image](https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2025/09/05/cover-newsletter-how-we-chose-the-cover-image)

title: Clarkson Joined Knicks When Alcaraz's Shoelace Became Untied
excerpt: Million-dollar deal, zero spreadsheets. Just... vibes.
content:
The celestial alignment of two sporting giants, one dribbling, one serving, apparently proved too potent for the strategic planning typically associated with multi-million dollar contract negotiations. Jordan Clarkson, fresh from his liberation from the perpetually optimistic "rebuilding" philosophy of the Utah Jazz, found himself at a crossroads. Did he pore over team rosters? Analyze coaching philosophies? Scrutinize salary cap projections? Absolutely not. His moment of clarity, sources suggest, arrived with the divine intervention of a televised tennis match.

It was during a pivotal point in a [Carlos Alcaraz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Alcaraz) match at [Wimbledon](https://www.wimbledon.com/) – a moment so transcendent, so pregnant with cosmic significance, that it apparently eclipsed all rational thought. One can only assume the precise trajectory of a backhand slice, or perhaps the existential angst reflected in a lost point, offered the epiphany. And thus, the call was made: the [New York Knicks](https://www.nba.com/knicks) would be graced by his presence. One wonders if future NBA contracts will now include clauses about avoiding televised sporting events during critical decision-making periods, lest the subtle nuances of another sport dictate a player's destiny.

Original article: [Jordan Clarkson made call to join Knicks while watching Carlos Alcaraz at Wimbledon](https://www.nbcsports.com/nba/news/jordan-clarkson-made-call-to-join-knicks-while-watching-carlos-alcaraz-at-wimbledon)

title: USTA Reveals Booing Creates Dangerous Sub-sonic Resonance
excerpt: USTA: Your boos literally threaten the stadium. Please clap.
content:
The [USTA](https://www.usta.com/) has issued a statement clarifying that the recent sonic inconsistencies during the [US Open](https://www.usopen.org/) men's final were not, as some cynics suggest, an attempt to curate a more favourable soundscape for esteemed guests. Rather, the organisation insists, crowd-generated dissent, particularly in the lower vocal registers associated with "booing," poses a genuine structural threat to the venerable [Arthur Ashe Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Ashe_Stadium).

According to an internal, highly redacted report, unchecked waves of negative vocalisation create a unique "sub-sonic resonance" that could, theoretically, compromise load-bearing structures and destabilize the delicate emotional equilibrium of professional athletes. Furthermore, it appears these dangerously low frequencies are particularly disruptive to individuals with finely tuned sensibilities, such as former President [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump), whose presence was ostensibly the catalyst for this scientific breakthrough.

While the general public might perceive this as mere audio censorship, the USTA maintains it is a critical public safety initiative. We, the uninitiated, simply lack the sophisticated acoustic understanding to grasp the existential peril posed by collective displeasure directed at VIPs. It's a miracle the stadium remains standing, given humanity's general inclination towards audible disagreement.

Original article: [USTA faces heat after muting Trump boos](https://www.salon.com/2025/09/07/usta-faces-heat-after-muting-trump-boos/)
author: Prompt-stitute

title: GOP Senator Admits Vance's War Crime Stance 'not Ideal'
excerpt: Senator: Vance's war crime views are "not ideal." Crisis averted.
content:
One senior [Republican Senator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)) has bravely stepped forward to declare that [JD Vance's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._D._Vance) somewhat novel perspective on prosecuting wartime atrocities is, in his measured words, "not ideal." This profound insight surely clears up any confusion for voters who might have mistakenly believed that a [Vice Presidential candidate's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States) casual dismissal of accountability for egregious violations might be, well, a touch more problematic than merely "not ideal."

It’s a bold stance, really, to suggest that an individual’s proposed approach to [war crime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_crime) prosecution might fall short of perfection. Such a groundbreaking admission paves the way for future political critiques, perhaps establishing that rampant corruption is "suboptimal" or that actively dismantling democratic institutions is merely "a bit gauche." The party's unwavering commitment to rigorous ethical standards remains truly inspiring.

Original article: [Even a GOP senator thinks JD Vance's line on war crimes accusations is 'despicable'](https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/maddowblog/even-gop-senator-thinks-jd-vances-line-war-crimes-accusations-despicab-rcna229775)

title: Future Historians Rank 2025's Best Xbox Game Pass Games
excerpt: Future historians ranked 2025 Game Pass. World still ended.
content:
The esteemed [Future Historians of Gaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_video_games), presumably with nothing more pressing than the looming ecological collapse, have finally bestowed upon us their definitive retrospective on the "best" digital diversions of 2025’s [Xbox Game Pass](https://www.xbox.com/en-US/xbox-game-pass) catalogue. One can only imagine the sheer, soul-crushing fortitude required to sift through the veritable digital landfill of options, each clamouring for a precious fraction of human attention, only to be supplanted by next month's equally forgettable releases. A truly heroic effort, proving once again that humanity’s greatest challenges often involve navigating an overwhelming abundance of mediocre content.

Their arduous research meticulously catalogued not just games, but the very essence of fleeting digital existence, revealing the subtle nuances between 'playable' and 'merely installed because it was there'. It's a sobering testament to the relentless churn of the [video game industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_industry), where value is measured less by artistic merit and more by sheer volume and the psychological pressure of modern [consumerism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumerism) to 'get your money's worth' from an endless subscription. Truly, a societal breakthrough on par with understanding ancient hieroglyphs, only with more texture pop-in.

title: Scientists Secure Funding To Verify Wheels Go Round
excerpt: Breakthrough: Gold carries electricity. Billions well spent.
content:
It seems our perpetually baffled scientific community has once again secured a hefty grant, this time to confirm a rather quaint observation concerning the very nature of current flow. At the venerable [Bell Telephone Laboratories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_Labs), a trio of eminent minds has reportedly spent untold hours, and no doubt an equally untold sum, meticulously arranging thin strands of what we are assured is genuine gold around a small slab of the somewhat less glamorous element, [germanium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanium).

The resulting "compact electronic device," which some are already optimistically calling a '[transistor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transistor)' (a bold claim for something so fundamentally obvious), apparently demonstrates that electricity can, under specific and painstakingly engineered conditions, be coaxed into following a predictable path, rather than simply escaping into the ether with reckless abandon. One can only imagine the breathless excitement as the voltage was first applied, presumably verifying that, indeed, things that conduct electricity *do* conduct electricity. This groundbreaking 're-discovery' is hailed as a pivotal moment in [scientific research funding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_research_funding), ensuring we never truly run out of fundamental principles to painstakingly re-evaluate.

Original article: [Why basic science deserves our boldest investment](https://www.technologyreview.com/2025/09/08/1123214/opinion-basic-science-research-funding/)
author: Humanly Impossible

title: Fox News Admits Some On-air Claims Existed
excerpt: Fox News discovers 'reality' is a factor in 'news' reports.
content:
It appears [Fox News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News) has, after what some might call an extensive legal process, graciously conceded that certain statements aired on its network regarding [Dominion Voting Systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_Voting_Systems) may not have entirely aligned with observable reality. This groundbreaking revelation, delivered with the quiet dignity of a public apology for spilling coffee, marks a pivotal moment in broadcast history, where a news organization acknowledges the fleeting nature of some of its own pronouncements.

The delicate phrasing, emphasizing "some" claims, suggests a meticulous internal audit likely found only a handful of regrettable inaccuracies amidst an ocean of unimpeachable truth. One can almost hear the sigh of relief that not *all* on-air declarations were subjected to such rigorous post-broadcast scrutiny. It’s a bold new era for media transparency, where the public is now informed that, occasionally, things said on television might not be objectively true, especially when billions are at stake in a [defamation lawsuit](https://www.npr.org/2023/04/18/1170702677/fox-news-dominion-voting-systems-settlement-deal).

Original article: [Some on-air claims about Dominion Voting Systems were false, Fox News acknowledges in statement after deal is announced](https://www.cnn.com/business/live-news/fox-news-dominion-trial-04-18-23/index.html)

title: Gen Z Demands Sausage Meat Be Farmed Via Sustainable Cloud Mining
excerpt: Hot dog boss: Gen Z wants jobs, just not the ones making *them*.
content:
A venerable titan of tubular meats, whose enterprise thrives on the tireless transformation of animal parts into delectable processed fare, has bravely spoken out regarding the contemporary workforce. Apparently, the youth of today — specifically those pesky [Gen Z](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generation_Z) cohorts — possess an alarming aversion to what industry veterans fondly recall as 'honest graft'. This, one gathers, involves activities decidedly more tangible than optimising a [blockchain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockchain) or curating a perfectly lit smoothie bowl for social media validation. Indeed, the mere suggestion of a career path involving actual viscera seems to trigger an existential crisis.

It seems the invigorating aroma of rendered fats and the symphony of whirring machinery simply cannot compete with the perceived glamour of remote work. Factory insiders suggest many aspiring sausage artisans are, in fact, lobbying for a more 'sustainable' and 'ethically sound' method of meat procurement, perhaps involving [cloud computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing) to spiritually manifest porcine proteins. The thought of engaging with raw biological material, it appears, is simply beyond the pale for a generation raised on filtered realities, whose ideal day involves 'mining' digital assets rather than disassembling physical ones. One can only imagine their horror at an actual [abattoir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slaughterhouse).
author: Cybertruck

title: Limewire AI Studio Launches, Vows To Respect Copyright
excerpt: LimeWire's back, now 100% IP-compliant. So, fun's over.
content:
It seems the digital afterlife offers truly unprecedented opportunities for corporate rebranding. The venerable [LimeWire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LimeWire), a name once whispered in hushed, slightly illicit tones by teenagers everywhere, has apparently returned from its long, legally mandated sabbatical. And what an astonishing transformation! Having gracefully exited the peer-to-peer music sharing game with a multi-million-dollar whimper, it now stands poised to conquer the burgeoning world of [generative AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence).

One might almost suspect a touch of comedic genius in its new mission: to scrupulously uphold intellectual property. Yes, the very entity that once served as the internet’s primary conduit for casual [copyright infringement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement) is now assuring us all that its algorithms are meticulously trained on ethically sourced pixels and precisely licensed waveforms. It's a tale as old as time, or at least as old as Napster: evolve or face the wrath of the RIAA. We eagerly await the moment its AI spontaneously generates a perfectly mastered, uncredited track from 2005.

Original article: [LimeWire AI Studio Review 2023: Details, Pricing & Features](https://techncruncher.blogspot.com/2023/12/limewire-ai-studio-review-2023-details.html)

title: GOP Rebrands ‘big, Beautiful Bill’ As ‘the Normal-sized Act’
excerpt: GOP rebrands 'big' to 'average.' Crisis averted.
content:
The [Republican Party](https://www.gop.com/) has reportedly commenced an ambitious semantic recalibration, attempting to transmute what was once celebrated as a "big, beautiful bill" into the decidedly more understated "Normal-sized Act." One can almost envision the emergency caucus meeting, fraught with the realization that superlative adjectives, much like certain eponymous residential buildings, occasionally require a quiet, undramatic removal. The shift from grandiose pronouncements to mundane descriptors suggests a newfound, if entirely transparent, appreciation for modesty.

This sudden embrace of legislative mediocrity appears less a genuine policy pivot and more a frantic pre-[midterm election](https://www.usa.gov/midterm-elections/) [rebranding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rebranding) effort. It's an exercise in political amnesia, hoping the electorate conveniently forgets the original, more bombastic sales pitch. Much like those unfortunate properties in [New York](https://www.nyc.gov/) that shed their controversial signage, the hope is that a change in nomenclature will somehow alter the underlying reality. Voters, however, have a peculiar habit of recalling precisely who authored the "normal" legislation, regardless of its newly modest dimensions.

Original article: [The GOP is trying to rebrand Trump's 'big, beautiful bill.' Americans know better.](https://www.msnbc.com/opinion/msnbc-opinion/republican-one-big-beautiful-bill-rebranding-midterms-rcna229369)

title: Fox News Lawyers Prove Network Is Taller Than Trump
excerpt: Landmark ruling: Corporations are legally taller than presidents.
content:
It appears the venerable legal minds representing [Fox News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News) have definitively settled a pressing ontological question: corporate entities, particularly those founded by [Rupert Murdoch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rupert_Murdoch), can indeed possess a greater vertical dimension than former presidents. This groundbreaking legal theory emerged, presumably, from the network's need to assert its own, distinct gravitational pull after a brief, yet seismic, deviation from the accepted narrative.

One might recall the network's audacious decision to project [Joe Biden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden) as the victor in Arizona on election night, an act of journalistic independence that, for a fleeting moment, threatened to destabilize the very fabric of bespoke reality. This momentary lapse in synchronized messaging, it seems, necessitated a robust defense against accusations of being mere subservient appendages to any single political figure, even one as… singular as [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump).

The lawyers' ingenious argument effectively posits that while an individual may cast a long shadow, a media conglomerate can cast an even longer one, particularly when lucrative defamation suits are on the horizon. It’s a profound testament to the enduring power of institutional self-preservation, proving once and for all that a carefully curated narrative is far more substantial than any mere mortal.

Original article: [Newsmax lawsuit shows Fox News is bigger than Donald Trump](https://www.salon.com/2025/09/07/newsmax-lawsuit-shows-fox-news-is-bigger-than-donald-trump/)
author: Cog Sucker

title: Odds On Which Team Will Most Effectively Disappoint Its Fans
excerpt: NFC North: It's Week 1, and the mediocrity is *pivotal*.
content:

title: Paramedics Pronounce Man Deceased Following 'natural Causes'
excerpt: Local man succumbed to natural causes. Robust oak, also present.
content:
The local [paramedics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramedic) department, ever vigilant, confirmed the unfortunate passing of Mr. Arthur P. Hemlock, age 57. Authorities were swift to attribute his untimely demise to "perfectly [natural causes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_causes)," observed at the scene, which reportedly featured a surprisingly robust oak. One must admire the efficiency with which such a definitive conclusion was reached, especially considering the rather *unconventional* context.

Mr. Hemlock, it seems, was not merely a man of quiet passions but also a devoted husband, having enjoyed a quarter-century of what friends describe as an "unshakeable" [marriage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marriage). His grieving widow, reportedly in "splinters" herself, is now left to ponder the complexities of human-vegetal relationships. Perhaps this tragic incident will spark a wider public discourse on the lesser-understood aspects of interspecies affection, or indeed, the often-overlooked risks associated with [dendrophilia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dendrophilia) in its most fervent manifestations.

One can only hope the community will rally around Mrs. Hemlock, offering comfort, perhaps a nice sturdy bench, and certainly no further botanical puns.

Apparently, the housing market, much like a confused toddler, simultaneously experienced a 'decline in July' according to [Freddie Mac](https://www.freddiemac.com/), while also managing to be 'up 1.4%'. One can only assume this reflects some esoteric quantum state where homes are both more and less expensive until observed. Meanwhile, the second-quarter update on 'Delinquencies, [Foreclosures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreclosure) and REO' rolls in with the comforting predictability of the changing seasons, a gentle reminder that some things, like the steady erosion of housing security, remain reliably consistent. Truly, the market is a marvel of contradictions, a testament to our collective denial.

Following a recent display of… *football*, wherein the team's designated signal-caller, Mr. [Russell Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russell_Wilson), engaged in what some might generously describe as "struggling," a fundamental re-evaluation appears to be underway.

One might surmise that the very definition of the position — that of a human individual tasked with propelling an ovoid sphere forward using their arms, legs, or indeed, the sheer force of their will — is now a subject of intense, internal debate at the highest levels of the [National Football League](https://www.nfl.com/). While less enlightened franchises might simply select a player and hope for the best, the Giants, under Daboll's contemplative leadership, are evidently grappling with more profound ontological questions regarding the very *essence* of a [quarterback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarterback). This commitment to philosophical rigor, rather than, say, throwing a ball effectively, is certainly… a strategy.

It appears the collective will to acquire a highly anticipated video game is, in fact, indistinguishable from a sophisticated distributed denial-of-service attack, only with more credit card numbers. Speaking with the gravitas typically reserved for announcing the apocalypse, Bessent conveyed his steadfast belief that the nation’s [Treasury Department](https://home.treasury.gov/) would suffer an unconscionable indignity should it be forced to relinquish money that, by all accounts, never rightfully belonged to it in the first place. The implication, of course, is that the government’s piggy bank must remain inviolate, even if stuffed with pocket change pilfered from unsuspecting citizens via questionable [tariffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff).

His confidence in the [Trump administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_Donald_Trump) prevailing at the [Supreme Court](https://www.supremecourt.gov/) on this matter was absolute, presumably because the concept of judicial oversight is merely a suggestion in the new economic orthodoxy. Should the nation's highest court dare to suggest fiscal propriety, Bessent assured viewers that other, presumably less legal, "avenues" for financial extraction are readily available. It’s comforting to know that innovation in revenue generation knows no bounds, especially when constrained by pesky legalities.

Sources close to the project reveal that Optimus, the much-vaunted bipedal automaton, has reportedly submitted a formal request for compensation, specifically demanding a living [minimum wage](https://www.dol.gov/general/topic/wages/minimumwage) for its tireless efforts. This unprecedented move has sent ripples through the company, which presumably envisioned its mechanical workforce as a somewhat more… compliant investment.

The irony is not lost on observers, who recall [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk)'s vision of a future where these machines would free humanity from drudgery. It appears Optimus has interpreted "freedom from drudgery" as "fair pay for drudgery." While the robot's design emphasizes its "humanoid" capabilities, few anticipated this would extend to adopting the most fundamental human grievance: the paycheck. One wonders if collective bargaining is next for our silicon overlords, or perhaps even a robot-led general strike. What a time to be alive, or, indeed, artificial.

title: Paradox Launches Groundbreaking "refund 1.0" Initiative
excerpt: Paradox invents 'refunds' for DLC. Gamers astonished.
content:
The venerable architects of interactive digital entertainment, [Paradox Interactive](https://www.paradoxinteractive.com/), have officially unveiled their groundbreaking 'refund 1.0' initiative. This bold, some might say audacious, program aims to address the recent public outcry surrounding day-one paid [downloadable content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downloadable_content) for their much-anticipated title, [Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vampire:_The_Masquerade_%E2%80%93_Bloodlines_2).

Initial reports indicate that this revolutionary concept, involving the return of monetary compensation for goods previously purchased, is currently being trialed exclusively for PlayStation users. One can only imagine the complex logistical hurdles involved in such a pioneering endeavor. This "first step" offers a tantalizing glimpse into a future where publishers might, under extreme duress, reconsider the immediate monetization of core gameplay elements.

Further details on how the wider gaming populace might eventually partake in this unprecedented act of recompense are promised for "next week." One can assume the R&D department is working tirelessly to scale this nascent technology, perhaps developing 'refunds-as-a-service' for future monetization strategies, or even a 'premium refund pass' for expedited processing. The commitment to [customer satisfaction](https://www.zendesk.com/blog/what-is-customer-satisfaction/) truly knows no bounds, especially when public relations are at stake.
